questions.text: Match the following? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. i. = c, ii. = a, iii. = d, iv. = b

 

i) Heroine = c) Brown sugar

 

ii) Joint = a) Ganja

 

iii) LSD = d) Acid

 

iv) Eve = b) Amphetamine

 

Explanation:

 

  • i. Heroin = c. Brown sugar
    • Heroin is a semi-synthetic opioid also known by street names such as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk.
  • ii. Joint = a. Ganja
    • A joint is a term used for a rolled marijuana cigarette. Ganja is also known as pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • iii. LSD = d. Acid
    • LSD is known by various street names including acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple owle.
  • iv. Eve = b. Amphetamine
    • Methamphetamine and related substances are often referred to as Eve, meth, etc.

 

Educational Objective

 

Street names of narcotic substances

 

  • Ganja is called Pot, grass, weed, rope, mull, dope, joint, Mary Jane, skunk, hash, reefer.
  • Heroin is a semisynthetic opioid also known as brown sugar, smack, dope, junk
  •   Cocaine is called by names like snuff, Rock, Crack, Coke, Snow, Cadillac, White lady
  • Methamphetamine is also called eve, meth etc.
  • LSD is called by names like acid, blotter acid, blue caps, blue dots, brown caps, crackers, purple Owle.
  • Abrus Precatorius is called by names like Indian liquor ice, prayer head, crab's eye, weather plant, gulagunchi, ratti, gunja.
  • Capsaicin is called by names like 'Hunan hand' as it causes burning of fingers.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a history of chronic arthritis on treatment came with complaints of defective vision in both eyes. On examination, vision in RE = 6/12, LE = 6/18, IOP = 18 mmHg in both eyes, and the anterior segment was normal. The fundus examination and fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) findings are shown in the figure. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine toxicity

 

The patient's history of taking medication for rheumatoid arthritis and fundus with a bull's eye sign, along with the FFA image showing increased fluorescence in the macular area and round-shaped blocked fluorescence in the central fovea, suggest likely chloroquine toxicity. Here are some key points about chloroquine toxicity:

 

  • Prolonged administration of chloroquine may lead to a keratopathy, myopathy, retinopathy, and optic neuropathy.
  • Chloroquine retinopathy is a serous pigmentary degeneration of the retina that may result in vision loss.
  • A mild pigmentary disturbance in the macular area causes visual field defects, particularly a central scotoma, and a characteristic "bull's-eye" retinal lesion that can be seen on fluorescein angiography.
  • Eventually, there is a widespread retinal atrophy with pigment clumping and attenuated retinal vessels.
  • Short-term use of chloroquine can produce blurring of vision and diplopia, which is reversible upon stopping the drug.
  • Hydroxychloroquine has a lower risk of ocular toxicity than chloroquine, but it has a weaker anti-inflammatory effect.
  • The maximum dose allowed for chloroquine is 6 mg/kg in 24 hours, while for hydroxychloroquine, it is 4.5 mg/kg. Hydroxychloroquine is more commonly used today at a dose of 300-400 mg/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choroiditis: This condition usually presents with patches of inflammation in the choroid, which are not observed in the provided images.

 

Option C. Steroid-induced glaucoma: This would more typically involve elevated intraocular pressure and optic nerve changes, which were not reported in the patient's examination.

 

Option D. Macular edema: While this might also involve changes in the macular region, it generally does not present with the specific "bull's eye" pattern seen in chloroquine toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRI


MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) does not use ionizing radiation. Instead, it employs strong magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images of the organs and structures inside the body. This makes MRI an important diagnostic tool, particularly useful for imaging soft tissues without the risks associated with ionizing radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha particles: These are a type of ionizing radiation consisting of helium nuclei and are known to be highly ionizing but with low penetration power.

 

Option B. Gamma rays: Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation, like X-rays, but typically have even higher energy levels and are certainly ionizing, capable of penetrating deep into biological tissues and causing ionization.

 

Option D. X-rays: X-rays are a well-known form of electromagnetic ionizing radiation used widely in medical imaging to view the structure of the body, particularly bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ionizing Radiation

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum
Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to umbilicus
Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus

questions.text: As an intern in emergency ward, which of the following method would you consider as correct regarding nasogastric tube length estimation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tip of nose to ear to xiphisternum (i.e., N-E-X)

 

Approximate length of nasogastric tube is 120 -125cm     

 

How to confirm correct position of NG tube:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • x-ray chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

 

 

XIPHISTERNUM

 

Place the tip of the nasogastric tube at the tip of the nose, then measure from the nose to the ear lobe & down to the tip of the Xiphisternum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tip of nose to angle of ear to umbilicus: This measurement is too long as it typically extends beyond the stomach, potentially reaching into the intestines.

 

Option C. Mouth to ear to umbilicus: This measurement is also incorrect and typically used for other medical estimations, not for NG tube placement.

 

Option D. Mouth to ear to midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus: Similar to option B, this measurement is excessively long for proper NG tube placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting a nasogastric tube, the correct measurement to estimate the necessary tube length is from the tip of the nose to the earlobe to the xiphisternum, ensuring the tube reaches the stomach properly for effective therapeutic or diagnostic use.

questions.text: Cardiac output can be determined using the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Capnography

 

Explanation:

 

Capnography primarily measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air, which gives information about ventilation and metabolism. It does not measure cardiac output. Capnography is commonly used to monitor end-tidal CO2 and confirm tracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thermal dilution technique: The thermal dilution technique is a method used primarily with a pulmonary artery catheter (also known as a Swan-Ganz catheter). Cold saline is injected into the right atrium, and the change in blood temperature is measured as it passes a thermistor in the pulmonary artery. The degree of temperature change allows for the calculation of cardiac output. This method is invasive and provides continuous or intermittent measurements, depending on the specific catheter and monitor used.

 

Option C. Esophageal Doppler: The esophageal Doppler uses ultrasound waves to measure blood flow velocity in the descending aorta via a probe placed in the esophagus. By knowing the cross-sectional area of the aorta and calculating the velocity of blood flow, cardiac output can be estimated.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Echocardiography, or cardiac ultrasound, allows for visualization of cardiac structures and blood flow. Cardiac output can be estimated by measuring the velocity of blood flow across the mitral or tricuspid valves and then multiplying this by the valve area.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air and is not used to determine cardiac output.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is relative bradycardia commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above


Relative bradycardia, also known as Faget's sign, occurs when a patient's heart rate is lower than expected relative to an elevated body temperature. Normally, an increase in body temperature causes the heart rate to increase by approximately 15-20 beats per minute for every 1°C rise. However, in relative bradycardia, this expected increase in heart rate is absent or diminished.

 

Relative bradycardia is not highly sensitive or specific as a diagnostic marker but can be helpful in clinical settings, especially where advanced diagnostic resources are limited.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Typhoid fever:  Caused by Salmonella typhi, typhoid fever is a well-known infectious cause of relative bradycardia.

 

Option B. Q fever:  Caused by Coxiella burnetii, Q fever is another infection linked with relative bradycardia.

 

Option C. Leptospirosis:  Caused by Leptospira interrogans, leptospirosis is also associated with relative bradycardia in certain cases.

 

Educational Objective:


Causes of relative bradycardia:

 

 

Relative bradycardia is often associated with infections caused by organisms that are both gram-negative and intracellular.

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Localized varicella zoster

 

  • Droplet precautions and isolation are unnecessary for localized varicella-zoster, as this virus is exclusively transmitted through direct contact.
  • When varicella-zoster remains confined to a patient with a fully functioning immune system and can be effectively contained or covered, there is no need for droplet precautions.
  • However, if varicella becomes disseminated in any patient, it necessitates both airborne and contact precautions.
  • On the other hand, diseases like diphtheria, pertussis, and mycoplasma are transmitted via droplets and, therefore, demand droplet precautions and isolation measures.
  • These precautions include the use of masks, gowns, gloves, and protective eye gear when delivering direct patient care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pertussis: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Requires droplet precautions as it is spread through respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumonia: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

choices.text: Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children
The no flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children.
More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children
Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

questions.text: True regarding the difference between adult and pediatric resuscitation? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dysrhythmias are most often due to respiratory insufficiency in children

 

In pediatric patients, dysrhythmias (abnormal heart rhythms) are more likely to be caused by respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia rather than intrinsic cardiac issues, which are more common causes of dysrhythmias in adults. Hypoxia and respiratory failure are the leading causes of cardiac arrest in children, as their cardiovascular systems are generally healthy compared to adults, where coronary artery disease is more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular dysrhythmias are common in children: Ventricular dysrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, are relatively uncommon in children. In pediatric patients, the most common dysrhythmias requiring treatment are supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and bradycardia, often secondary to hypoxia or other respiratory issues.

 

Option B. The no-flow phase precedes the period of cardiac arrest in children: The no-flow phase refers to the period between the onset of cardiac arrest and the initiation of effective CPR. While this phase occurs in both adults and children, it does not specifically precede cardiac arrest. The phases of cardiac arrest include the pre-arrest phase, the no-flow phase, the low-flow phase (which begins with CPR), and the post-resuscitation phase (which begins with the return of spontaneous circulation).

 

Option C. More ventilation to be given compared to chest compressions in children: The correct chest compression to ventilation ratio in pediatric CPR is either 30:2 or 15:2, depending on whether one or two rescuers are present. Providing excessive ventilation can decrease venous return, reduce coronary and cerebral blood flow, lower cardiac output, and ultimately decrease the chances of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). Therefore, the emphasis is on high-quality chest compressions with appropriate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric resuscitation, dysrhythmias are most commonly due to respiratory insufficiency or hypoxia, unlike in adults, where intrinsic cardiac causes are more prevalent.

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased sleep: Individuals might sleep more than usual.

 

Option B. Reactive mood: While the individuals typically have a depressed mood, their mood can temporarily lift in response to positive events.

 

Option C. Heaviness of the body: Often described as "leaden paralysis," especially in the arms and legs.

 

However, the claim that atypical depression responds better to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) than to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) is incorrect. In reality, atypical depression often responds better to SSRIs & MAO-Is than to TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), presence of mood reactivity, leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection. SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

questions.text: Which muscle is not involved in the inversion of foot? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Peroneus longus

 

The peroneus longus is a muscle of the lateral compartment of the leg. It originates from the head and upper two-thirds of the fibula, and it has a long tendon that wraps behind the lateral malleolus and extends to the medial side of the foot, inserting into the base of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform. When the peroneus longus contracts, it everts the foot and also plantarflexes the ankle. Therefore, the peroneus longus is not involved in the inversion of the foot.

 

Inversion of the foot is a movement in which the medial border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces medially.

 

  • Tibialis anterior - Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot
  • Tibialis posterior - Plantar flexion and inversion of the foot
  • Extensor hallucis longs - Extension of the great toe, dorsiflexion of the foot, and inversion of the foot (minimal action)

 

Eversion of the foot is a movement where the lateral border of the foot is elevated so that the sole faces laterally.

 

  • Peroneus longus, peroneus brevis, and peroneus tertius are the muscles involved.

 

These movements take place, mainly at the talocalcaneal and the talocalcaneonavicular joints, and partly at the transverse tarsal joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: The tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the lateral surface of the tibia and inserts into the medial cuneiform and first metatarsal bones of the foot. When this muscle contracts, it dorsiflexes the ankle (pulls the foot upwards, towards the shin) and inverts the foot. Therefore, the tibialis anterior plays a role in foot inversion.

 

Option B. Tibialis posterior: The tibialis posterior is located in the deep compartment of the leg. It originates from the posterior surfaces of the tibia and fibula and inserts into various bones in the foot, including the navicular, cuneiforms, and metatarsals. When the tibialis posterior contracts, it plantarflexes the ankle (points the foot downward) and also inverts the foot. Like the tibialis anterior, the tibialis posterior is involved in foot inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: The extensor hallucis longus is another muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. It originates from the anterior surface of the fibula and the interosseous membrane and inserts into the distal phalanx of the big toe. Its primary action is to dorsiflex the big toe. While it plays a role in dorsiflexion of the ankle, its contribution to inversion or eversion is minimal compared to the other muscles listed. However, it can assist in inversion to a minor extent when combined with other inverters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peroneus longus muscle is not involved in the inversion of the foot. It causes eversion and plantar flexion.

 

The transverse tarsal joint and the talocalcaneal and talocalcaneonavicular joints also play a role in inversion and eversion movements

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

 

The clinical presentation described, including coarse facial features, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and copious mucus discharge from the nose, is characteristic of Hurler disease. Hurler disease is a severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS 1), which results from a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, specifically heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, in various tissues.

 

Key Clinical Features of Hurler Disease:

 

  • Coarse facial features: The facial appearance is often described as "gargoyle-like" due to the thickening of facial structures.
  • Macroglossia and thick lips: Enlargement of the tongue and thickened lips are common in Hurler disease.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is a typical finding.
  • Corneal clouding: Although not mentioned in the question, this is another characteristic finding in Hurler disease.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: These include joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement: Patients may experience recurrent respiratory infections, noisy breathing, and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: This is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by features such as macrosomia (large body size), macroglossia, hemihypertrophy (asymmetrical body growth), omphalocele (abdominal wall defect), and an increased risk of certain cancers like Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. However, the combination of features presented in this case aligns more closely with Hurler disease.

 

Option C. Proteus Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by overgrowth of bones, skin, and other tissues. It does not typically present with the features described in the question, such as coarse facies, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious mucus discharge.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: While congenital hypothyroidism can present with macroglossia and coarse facial features, it typically does not cause the combination of symptoms described in this case, such as hepatosplenomegaly and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text: What is the main action of the muscle marked below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Elevation

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in the image is the temporalis and its main action is elevation of the mandible.

 

Other actions are:

 

  • ﻿﻿It helps in the side-to-side grinding movements of the mandible.
  • ﻿﻿The posterior fibres which are horizontal, help in the retraction of the mandible.

 

The muscles of mastication are a group of four muscles that are responsible for the movements of the jaw during chewing (mastication). These muscles include:

 

Together, these muscles work to elevate and depress the mandible, move it side to side, and protrude it forward. They are important for chewing, speaking, and swallowing. Dysfunction of these muscles can result in temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders and other oral health problems.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: This action is not associated with the temporalis muscle. Depression of the mandible, which involves opening the jaw, is primarily accomplished by the digastric muscle and, to some extent, by the lateral pterygoid muscle.

 

Option C. Protrusion: Protrusion refers to pushing the jaw forward. This action is chiefly performed by the lateral pterygoid muscle, not the temporalis.

 

Option D. Retraction: While the posterior fibers of the temporalis muscle do assist in retraction of the mandible, pulling it backward, it is not the primary action of the entire muscle. The main retractor of the jaw is the posterior part of the temporalis muscle alongside the digastric muscle (posterior belly).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) В>А>С

 

  • ﻿﻿The above graph is a pressure-volume relationship showing the relationship between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • ﻿﻿The graphs show the lung compliance which is the change in lung volume with change in intrapleural pressure.
  • A steeper curve implies more compliance while a flatter curve implies less compliance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steepness of the pressure-volume curve indicates lung compliance. In this graph, lung B has the highest compliance, lung A has moderate compliance, and lung C has the lowest compliance.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

 

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, including the brainstem. It is a clinical diagnosis based on the absence of neurological function and the irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous respiration.

 

In brain death, the following clinical observations can be present and may be mistakenly interpreted as signs of brainstem function, but they do not indicate any meaningful brain activity:

 

Things That Can Be Present in Brain Death- 

  1. Normal blood pressure without drugs
  2. Spinal reflexes
    1. Movements like Babinski, deep tendon reflexes may be seen.
    2. These come from the spinal cord, not the brain
  3. Sweating or tachycardia
    1. Autonomic responses — do not indicate brain activity.
  4. What is Not Seen in Brain Death:
    1. Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
      1. These need some brain activity
      2. In brain death: no such posturing happens — total motor silence.


         

 

However, decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not seen in brain death. These postures are indicative of severe brain injury but require some level of brain activity to generate the motor response. In brain death, all brain-originating motor responses, including these postures, are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal BP without pharmacological support: Autonomic responses may still maintain blood pressure without brain function, making this observation consistent with brain death.

 

Option B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation: These reflexes are mediated by the spinal cord, not the brain, and thus can still occur in brain death.

 

Option C. Sweating and tachycardia: These autonomic functions can persist despite brain death due to residual autonomic nervous system activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

questions.text: The patient presented with symptoms of fever, body ache, and joint pain, and was treated with NSAIDs. Subsequently, a few days later, the patient developed brownish pigmentation on the nose. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig. Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 118, Page no 118.11

HARRISONS PRINCIPLES OF INTERNAL MEDICINE 21ST EDITION PAGE 141-142, 1633

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drusen  

 

  • Drusen, also called colloid bodies, are extracellular deposits located at the interface between the Retinal Pigmentary Epithelium and Bruch membrane.
  • Drusen are numerous, minute, whitish, refractile spots with pigmented margins, mainly involving the posterior pole.
  • They are seen in senile macular degeneration and Doyne's honeycomb dystrophy.
  • The material of which they are composed has a broad range of constituents and is thought to be derived from immune-mediated and metabolic processes in the retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • The precise role of drusen in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is unclear.
  • However, drusen are positively associated with the size of lesions and the presence or absence of associated pigmentary abnormalities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hard exudates: Well-defined, bright yellow deposits of extravasated fluid rich in fibrin and proteins. These hyaline or lipid deposits are generally seen as a cluster around a group of leaking microaneurysms. Commonly seen in macular area, in the outer plexiform layer.

 

Option C. Cotton-wool spots: Composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fibre layer.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Accumulation of excess fluid in the extracellular space within the retina in the macular area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drusen are distinct, granular deposits at the interface between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, commonly associated with age-related macular degeneration and can be an early sign of the disease.

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?  ? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

choices.text: Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

questions.text: A pregnant female with known cardiac disease presents in the first trimester with history of warfarin embryopathy. What should be advised now? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Replace warfarin with heparin in first trimester

 

Warfarin readily crosses the placenta and is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when exposure occurs between the 6th and 9th weeks of pregnancy. Warfarin embryopathy is characterized by stippled epiphysis and nasal hypoplasia.

 

Management guidelines for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves requiring anticoagulation:

 

  • First trimester: Women on warfarin should be switched to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed to avoid teratogenic effects.
  • Second and third trimesters (13 to 36 weeks): Warfarin can be resumed as it is the most effective anticoagulant in preventing thromboembolic events.
  • Near delivery: Warfarin should be switched back to heparin around delivery to avoid complications. Heparin should be stopped prior to delivery.

 

Mechanical heart valves: Require lifelong anticoagulation, whereas bioprosthetic valves do not require lifelong anticoagulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue warfarin throughout the pregnancy: Continuing warfarin throughout the pregnancy is not advisable due to the risk of warfarin embryopathy and potential fetal hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Give accoumarin: Accoumarin is not a standard recommendation for anticoagulation in pregnant women with mechanical heart valves.

 

Option D. Use LMW heparin: While low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is safer in pregnancy compared to warfarin, the specific recommendation is to switch to heparin in the first trimester and possibly back to warfarin in the second and third trimesters, depending on individual risk assessments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant women with mechanical heart valves on warfarin, switch to heparin as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed in the first trimester to avoid teratogenic effects, and manage anticoagulation carefully throughout the pregnancy to minimize risks to both mother and fetus.

 

 

Algorithm for management of women with prosthetic heart valves requiring anti-coagulation in pregnancy

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 2406

questions.text: A cook prepares sandwiches for 10 people going for picnic. Eight out of them develop severe gastroenteritis within 4-6 hrs. of consumption of the sandwiches. It is likely that on investigations the cook is found to be the carrier of: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The rapid onset of gastroenteritis symptoms within 4-6 hours after consuming the sandwiches suggests a preformed toxin in the food. Staphylococcus aureus is known for producing enterotoxins that cause food poisoning with a short incubation period of 2-6 hours. This bacterium can contaminate food through contact with a carrier who handles food without proper hygiene. In this case, the cook is likely the carrier, having contaminated the sandwiches, leading to the outbreak of gastroenteritis among the picnic attendees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, which has a longer incubation period (6-30 days), making it unlikely to cause symptoms so quickly.

 

Option B. Vibrio cholera: This bacterium causes cholera, characterized by severe diarrhea and dehydration, with an incubation period of a few hours to 5 days, but it typically results from contaminated water rather than food prepared by a cook.

 

Option C. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which generally has a longer incubation period (2-4 weeks), and it is usually associated with contaminated water or food.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During the insertion of a Ryle’s tube, what is the best position for a conscious patient to be in? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sitting with neck flexion

 

This is the best position for a conscious patient during Ryle's tube insertion. Sitting allows for better alignment of the upper gastrointestinal tract, making it easier to guide the tube through the esophagus and into the stomach. Neck flexion helps align the crico-pharynx with the Ryle’s tube, reducing faulty tracheal insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

 

Confirmation of the correct position of RT is done by:

 

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • X-ray chest + upper abdomen

 

The approximate length of the Ryle’s tube is 120-125 cm. There are 4 markings on the tube which indicates the traversing of the tube through various parts of the stomach

 

  1. 40 cm - Tube has traversed cardia of the stomach
  2. 50 cm - Tube has traversed body of the stomach
  3. 60 cm - Tube has traversed pylorus
  4. 70 cm - Tube has traversed duodenum

 

The length of tube to be inserted is calculated by measuring the distance between nose-tip of ear lobule-xiphoid (N-E-X rule).

questions.text: You're a physician attending a conference on emerging infectious diseases. As the discussion shifts towards the recent outbreaks in South India, the speaker displays an image showcasing the life cycle of a specific virus. A fellow physician sitting beside you, being relatively unfamiliar with the recent disease trends in South India, asks for your insights about the virus in question. Given the depicted life cycle and the associated clinical syndromes, which of the following viruses would be the most likely culprit? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nipah virus

 

NIPAH Virus

 

  • Genus: Henapi virus
  • Transmission in India:
    • Occurrence: West Bengal, Kerela (Kozhikode district)
    • Route: Consumption of fruits contaminated with bats (Pteropus: ‘Flying foxes’) secretions (person - person in India) 
    • Direct contact with infected bats, infected pigs, infected people
  • Clinical presentation: Encephalitis
  • IP is 4-14 days
  • Case fatality rate: 50%
  • Vaccine: NONE for humans
  • Treatment: Intensive supportive care
    • High-risk contacts and healthcare workers, who are under quarantine and monitoring for 21 days
  • WHO included Nipah virus under list of Emerging Diseases likely to cause Major Epidemics 
  • Comes under Category C of Bioterrorism agent 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Japanese encephalitis: Transmitted by mosquitoes and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Option B. Zika virus: Transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes species, and does not match the transmission cycle shown in the image.

 

ZIKA VIRUS LIFE CYCLE

 

 

 

Option C. Rabies: Transmitted through the bites of infected animals (typically dogs or other mammals) and does not involve fruit bats or the depicted transmission cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nipah virus, transmitted through fruit bats and causing encephalitis, fits the transmission cycle shown in the image and is a significant emerging infectious disease in regions such as Malaysia and Bangladesh.

choices.text: Swan Neck deformity
Boutonniere deformity
Jersey Finger
Mallet Finger

questions.text: Identify the deformity:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Swan Neck deformity

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis: Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
    • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
      • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles
      • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
      • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Others:
      • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
      • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
      • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
      • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis in patients of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:
    • Hand:
      • ‘Z-deformity’, i.e. radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of the digits, often with palmar subluxation of proximal phalanges.
      • Boutonniere deformity i.e. flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.
      • Swan neck deformity i.e. hyperextension of PIP joints with compensatory flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints.

 

 

  • Elbow:
  • Flexion deformity
  • Knee:
  • Early: Flexion deformity
  • Late: Triple subluxation
  • Ankle:
  • Equinus deformity
  • Foot:
  • Hallux valgus, Hammer toe, etc.
  • Radiological Features:
  • Reduced joint space
  • Erosion of articular margins
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Juxta-articular rarefaction
  • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
  • Deformities of the hand and fingers

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Boutonniere deformity. It is the flexion contracture of PIP joints and hyperextension of DIP joints. It is due to rupture of extensor tendon.

 

 

Option C. Jersey finger. It is avulsion of FDP from distal phalanx. There is hyperextension of a flexed finger as in finger trapped in a jersey. Ring finger most commonly affected. Treatment is surgical.

 

 

Option D. Mallet finger. It is avulsion of extensor tendon of the distal interphalangeal joint from its insertion at the base of distal phalanx. It may be due to direct trauma, but more often occurs when the finger tip is forcibly bent during active extension (i.e. sudden occurrence of passive flexion of distal interphalangeal joint). The terminal phalanx is flexed, but passive movement is normal. The proximal interphalangeal joint may become hyper- extended due to unbalanced extensor mechanism (Swan neck). Three types are a tendinous avulsion (X-ray is normal), a small flake of bone or a large dorsal bone fragment, (some times with subluxation of Joints).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is of Swan Neck Deformity, which is seen in the cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inadequate patient preparation

 

Inadequate preparation of a patient with hyperthyroidism before thyroidectomy, such as not optimizing thyroid function and medication management, can increase the risk of thyroid storm. Proper preoperative management and stabilization of thyroid function are crucial to prevent this complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling during thyroid surgery can potentially lead to complications, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm.

 

Option B. Due to parathyroid gland injury: The parathyroid glands are separate from the thyroid gland and regulate calcium levels in the body. Complications involving the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery leading to postoperative hypocalcemia.

 

Option D. Infections: Infections can occur as complications after thyroid surgery, but they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is primarily related to the excessive release of thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A thyroid storm, also known as thyrotoxic crisis, is a rare but life-threatening medical emergency that occurs in individuals with severe hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism is a condition in which the thyroid gland produces an excessive amount of thyroid hormones, primarily thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). In a thyroid storm, these hormone levels become dangerously elevated, leading to a wide range of symptoms and complications.

 

Symptoms of a thyroid storm may include:

 

  1. High fever
  2. Rapid and irregular heartbeat (tachycardia)
  3. Elevated blood pressure
  4. Extreme agitation and restlessness
  5. Profuse sweating
  6. Tremors and shaking
  7. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea
  8. Delirium or confusion
  9. Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes)
  10. Coma (in severe cases)

 

Thyroid storms can be triggered by various factors, such as surgery, infection, trauma, or medication changes in individuals with underlying hyperthyroidism. The condition is more common in people with Graves' disease, a common cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Treatment of a thyroid storm is a medical emergency and typically involves a combination of interventions to rapidly lower thyroid hormone levels, control symptoms, and support vital organ function.

 

The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Thus, patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

choices.text: Karyotyping of the parents

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic sonography

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause of recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound (pelvic sonography) as it is non-invasive and provides detailed imaging of the uterine structure.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Recurrent first trimester abortions: Often associated with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) or endocrinological causes.
  • Recurrent second trimester abortions: Often associated with anatomical uterine problems.
  • Single spontaneous abortion: Most commonly caused by fetal genetic abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hysterosalpingography: This is not routinely advised for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. It is more commonly used for evaluating tubal patency and uterine cavity shape but is not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Endometrial Biopsy: This is advised in women with suspected genital tuberculosis or in women with suspected luteal phase defect. It is not typically indicated for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss.

 

Option D. Karyotyping of the parents: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as balanced translocations, account for only about 5% of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Therefore, parental karyotyping is not an initial investigation of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is pelvic sonography to evaluate for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 2t6h edition pg 203

questions.text: The fetal adrenal gland production of which of the following is maximum? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DHEA

 

The fetal adrenal gland primarily produces Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and its sulfate form, DHEA-S, in significant quantities during pregnancy. DHEA and DHEA-S are essential precursors for the synthesis of estrogens. These precursors are crucial because the fetal adrenal gland produces much more DHEA-S than the maternal adrenal gland, making it the most important source of estrogen precursors for the placenta.

 

During pregnancy, these estrogens play a vital role in maintaining the pregnancy and supporting fetal development. The high production of DHEA by the fetal adrenal gland underlines its significant contribution to the endocrine environment during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: While cortisol is produced by the fetal adrenal gland, its production is not as high as DHEA. Cortisol plays a role in fetal lung maturation, but it is not produced in maximum amounts compared to DHEA.

 

Option C. Corticosterone: Corticosterone is another steroid hormone produced by the adrenal gland but in much smaller quantities than DHEA.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily produced by the placenta during pregnancy, and the adrenal gland's contribution to its levels is minimal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fetal adrenal gland produces the maximum amount of DHEA, which is a precursor for estrogen synthesis, critical for maintaining pregnancy and supporting fetal development.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented with a hard painless testicular swelling. There were no inguinal, intra-abdominal or mediastinal lymph nodes on CT scan. The blood workup showed AFP levels of > 3000. USG shows uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis. The next line of management is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High inguinal orchidectomy  

 

This is the correct choice. In a young male presenting with a hard, painless testicular swelling and significantly elevated AFP levels (>3000), along with findings of uniform echotexture with small areas of necrosis on ultrasound (USG), there is a high suspicion of testicular cancer, particularly a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT). High inguinal orchidectomy is the standard initial surgical approach for the diagnosis and treatment of testicular cancer. The removed testicle is sent for pathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific type of tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Core needle trucut biopsy: Core needle biopsy is contraindicate for testicular masses because it carries the risk of tumor spread or seeding along the biopsy tract.

 

Option C. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): FNAC is also not the preferred option for testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding and difficulties in obtaining an accurate diagnosis for testicular cancer.

 

Option D. Whole body PET/CT: Whole body PET/CT is typically used for staging and evaluating the extent of cancer after a diagnosis is confirmed. It is not the initial step in diagnosing a testicular mass.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given features that point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) in stage I of the tumor. In a case of painless swelling of the testis, a testicular tumor should be suspected. The associated rise in AFP level points toward a diagnosis of NSGCT although tissue diagnosis is required to confirm the nature of the tumor. But tissue diagnosis is not a prerequisite for treatment, and hence, based on the available evidence a high inguinal orchidectomy is done in this case. Further treatment is followed up based on the findings of the excisional biopsy.

 

  • NSGCTs are not radiosensitive, but they are highly sensitive to combination chemotherapy with bleomycin, etoposide, and cis-platinum (BEP chemotherapy). Up to 30% of NSGCT patients with stage I disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse if surveillance alone is done after orchidectomy.
  • Accordingly, some NSGCTs with good prognoses can be managed by surveillance protocols (using regular CT scanning and tumor marker measurement), with the more high-risk cases receiving chemotherapy.
  • For NSGCTs a 5-year survival rate of more than 90% is achievable in patients with good prognosis tumors, while for more advanced tumors, the 5-year survival rate is about 60%.

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4 weeks
Repeat TVS after one week
Serum HCG levels

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat TVS after one week

 

In the case described, the patient has a gestational sac and a crown-rump length (CRL) of 5 mm, with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks based on transvaginal sonography (TVS). The guidelines for assessing early pregnancy viability are:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a mean sac diameter (MSD) ≥ 25 mm indicates an anembryonic pregnancy.
  • Absence of cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm indicates a non-viable pregnancy.

 

In this scenario, the CRL is 5 mm, which is below the threshold where the absence of cardiac activity would indicate a non-viable pregnancy (≥ 7 mm). There is no mention of cardiac activity in the current ultrasound findings, so it is crucial to monitor the pregnancy further before making any conclusions.

 

The best course of action is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to check for the presence of cardiac activity and further development of the embryo. This approach allows for a more accurate assessment of the viability of the pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch for 4 weeks: Waiting for 4 weeks without further evaluation could delay necessary medical intervention and is not recommended for timely assessment of pregnancy viability.

 

Option C. Serum HCG levels: While measuring serum HCG levels can provide some information about the progression of the pregnancy, it is less specific than ultrasound for determining viability, particularly in the context of assessing cardiac activity.

 

Option D. Medical intervention: Immediate medical intervention is not warranted at this stage without further evidence. The repeat ultrasound will provide more clarity on whether intervention is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy with a CRL of less than 7 mm and no documented cardiac activity, the best approach is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to reassess for the presence of cardiac activity and viability of the pregnancy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 645

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into brachiocephalic vein? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Left superior intercostal vein

 

Explanation:

 

The left superior intercostal vein  directly drain into the brachiocephalic vein. This vein collects venous blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiazygous Vein: The hemiazygous vein is a tributary of the azygos vein, not the brachiocephalic vein. It drains blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Option B. Superior Thyroid Vein : It drain into the internal jugular vein, not directly into the brachiocephalic vein. They carry blood from the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Right Superior Intercostal Vein: It is formed by union of 2nd, 3rd, and 4th right posterior intercostal veins). It drains into the azygous vein. It serves as a major channel for venous blood from the right side of the posterior thoracic wall to return to the superior vena cava and ultimately to the right atrium of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tributaries of the brachiocephalic vein:

 

  • Left and right internal thoracic veins
  • Left and right inferior thyroid veins
  • Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.
  • The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Out of the options given below, what is the cause of death in smoke inhalation? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anemic hypoxia

 

Smoke contains multiple substances, of which the most significant component is carbon monoxide (CO). CO can cause both anemic hypoxia as well as histotoxic hypoxia, but predominant cause is anemic hypoxia. Mechanism of hypoxia by CO:

 

  • Anemic Hypoxia by CO: CO combines with hb to form COHb) producing anemic hypoxia (blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced)
  • Histotoxic Hypoxia by CO: While the primary impact of CO is on blood oxygen transport, the presence of COHb can also interfere with cellular respiration at the tissue level. COHb affects mitochondrial function and the electron transport chain, disrupting the cells' ability to utilize the oxygen that is delivered to them.

 

Other options

 

Option A) Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when cells can’t effectively use the available oxygen

due to interference with crucial cellular processes. CO causes histotoxic hypoxia also but the main cause of death is anemic hypoxia. A typical example of histotoxic hypoxia is cyanide poisoning.

 

Option B) Ischemic hypoxia results from inadequate circulation due to conditions such as heart failure and hypoxia in the setting of shock.

 

Option D) All of the above it is incorrect as CO may cause anemic and histotoxic hypoxia but not ischemic hypoxia

 

Educational objective

 

Anemic hypoxia

 

  • Anemic hypoxia is hypoxia  caused by the decreased O2-carrying capacity of blood. It can occur due to two reasons:
    • Hb concentration is low, or
    • Hb concentration may be normal, but it is not able to bind to O2. It can occur due to following conditions:
      • CO Poisoning: It has a higher affinity for Hb than O2 forming COHb.
      • Methemoglobinemia: Methemoglobin is a form of Hb where the iron is in the ferric state (Fe3+) instead of the normal ferrous state (Fe2+). Methemoglobin cannot bind to oxygen effectively.
      • Certain Genetic Hemoglobin Disorders altering the structure of Hb, e.g.

Sickle cell anemia, thalassemia.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation

 

The image shows a blue-white assay which uses the phenomenon of complementation (complementation of the galactosidase gene).

 

Blue-white assay: The target DNA is inserted into a vector. Vector is introduced into host cells for transformation and it grows in the presence of X-gal (X-gal detects active galactosidase). White colonies arise when cells are transformed with recombinant DNA-containing vectors; blue colonies form when cells are transformed with non-recombinant plasmids (i.e., just the vector).

 

Interpretation of Colonies:

 

  • White Colonies: These arise when the lacZ gene is disrupted by the insertion of foreign DNA, preventing the production of active beta-galactosidase. This indicates successful insertion of the foreign DNA.
  • Green Colonies: (Typically represented as blue colonies in traditional descriptions) These form when the lacZ gene remains intact, producing active beta-galactosidase that cleaves X-Gal, resulting in a blue color. This indicates the vector did not take up the foreign DNA or the insert is outside the lacZ gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: This process involves the synthesis of proteins from mRNA and is not related to the phenomenon shown in the image.

 

Option B. Transformation: While transformation is a part of the process where bacterial cells take up the plasmid DNA, the specific phenomenon depicted is complementation in the blue-white screening assay.

 

Option D. Conjugation: This is a method of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria involving direct cell-to-cell contact and is unrelated to the process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue-white screening assay uses the complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene to distinguish between bacterial colonies with recombinant and non-recombinant plasmids based on the color change in the presence of X-Gal.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that passes through the marked foramen marked 2 in the image below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Oculomotor nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The marked structure is the superior orbital fissure and the oculomotor nerve passes through this fissure.

 

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring. The oculomotor nerve passes through its intermediate compartment.

 

 

The oculomotor nerve primarily controls the movements of several eye muscles, including the levator palpebrae superioris (lifts the upper eyelid), and the superior, inferior, and medial rectus muscles, which control eye movements. It also controls the constriction of the pupil (miosis) and accommodation of the lens for near vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Olfactory Nerve (CN I):

 

  • The olfactory nerve originates from the olfactory bulbs, which are extensions of the brain, located on the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone within the anterior cranial fossa.

 

  • The olfactory nerve is responsible for the sense of smell. It carries sensory information related to odors from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

Option C. Optic Nerve (CN II):

 

  • The optic nerve emerges from the optic canal, which is located in the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone within the middle cranial fossa.

 

  • The optic nerve is crucial for vision. It transmits visual information from the retina to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual stimuli.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • The facial nerve emerge from a stylomastoid foramen from the base of the skull.

 

  • It controls the muscles of facial expression, taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and the production of saliva and tears. It also carries sensory information related to taste.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following elements is not included in the provisions of the Mental Health Care Act of 2017, as per the WHO's mhGAP? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Screening of family members

 

  • The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 focuses on the rights and treatment of patients with mental illness, but it does not specifically include provisions for the screening of family members.
  • The Act covers various aspects such as the capacity to make healthcare decisions, advance directives, nominated representatives, types of admissions, bans on certain treatments (like direct ECT for minors and psychosurgery), decriminalization of suicide attempts, and regulations on restraints and seclusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mobilization of resources: The Act includes provisions related to the mobilization of resources for mental health services.

 

Option C. Social support: Social support is a crucial aspect of mental health care covered under the Act, ensuring that patients receive necessary support from family and community.

 

Option D. Interpersonal therapy: While specific therapies may not be explicitly listed, the Act does promote access to various mental health treatments, which can include interpersonal therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of family members is not included in the Mental Health Care Act, 2017.

 

Additional Information

 

MENTAL HEALTHCARE ACT, 2017 (MHCA 2017)

 

  • Deals with rights of patients with mental illness and treatment delivery. Important clauses-

 

A. Capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision- Every person, including patients with mental illness, are assumed to have it if they can-

 

  • Can understand the information provided to them
  • Understand the consequences of their decisions
  • Can communicate their decision

 

B. Advance directive- Every person (not a minor) can make an advance directive in which he can mention-

 

  • How they wish to be treated/not treated for a mental illness
  • Applicable only if a person loses the capacity to take mental healthcare or treatment decisions
  • Duty of psychiatrist (or medical officer) to give treatment according to the advance directive
  • Doctor is not liable in case of unforeseen consequences while following the advance directive

 

C. Nominated representative (NR)-

 

  • Every person can appoint a nominated representative
  • In case of loss of capacity to make mental healthcare and treatment decision, NR would help in taking decisions about treatment

 

D. Admission- MHCA 2017 allows two types of admissions

 

  • Independent admissions- When the patient himself wants to get admitted
  • Supported admission (for a maximum of 30 days)- A person who has lost the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions and requires significant support from a nominated representative can be admitted under a “supported admission”

 

E. Ban on direct ECT

 

F. Ban on ECT for minors

 

G. Ban on psychosurgery

 

H. Decriminalisation of suicide attempt - Any person who attempts suicide shall be presumed to be under severe stress and should not be tried or punished

 

I. Restraints and seclusions - A patient can be physically restrained only-

 

  • If it is the only way to prevent harm to self or others
  • If authorised by a psychiatrist in charge

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive stretch

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: Which of the following enhances iron absorption? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Option B: Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) – Correct Answer

  • Enhances iron absorption by:
    • Reducing ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) — the absorbable form.
    • Forms soluble complexes with iron in the gut, preventing precipitation.
       

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While important for overall health, it does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Essential for carbohydrate metabolism, but it does not affect iron absorption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Important for various metabolic processes but does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric ions (Fe+++) to ferrous ions (Fe++) and forming a chelate that protects iron from oxidation, thereby facilitating its absorption in the intestine.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Na, K

 

Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

 

During the early portion of the action potential, the ratio of sodium to potassium conductance increases more than 1000-fold. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

 

Then the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels to open, so that the ratio of conductance shifts far in favor of high potassium conductance but low sodium conductance. This allows very rapid loss of potassium ions to the exterior but virtually zero flow of sodium ions to the interior.

Consequently, the action potential quickly returns to its baseline level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During an action potential, sodium conductance increases first (Channel A), followed by an increase in potassium conductance (Channel B), causing depolarization and subsequent repolarization of the neuron.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture sustained in a motorcycle accident? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hinge fracture

 

Image shows a transverse fracture of the base of the skull that completely splits it and divide it into two halves, each moving independently of each other like a hinge (‘nodding face’ sign).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Depressed fracture of skull: When a portion of fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as depressed fracture. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Pond fracture is the other name of pediatric depressed skull fracture. It is primarily due to increased plasticity of the immature skeleton in young children. The picture in the question have a transverse fracture dividing the base of the skull and is not a depressed fracture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option D) Comminuted fracture of skull: is when two or more intersecting lines of fracture divide the bone into three or more fragments resembling a spider web or mosaic pattern this is not the case in this picture hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

‘Hinge’ (also called Motorcyclist):

 

  • linear fracture passes across the middle cranial fossa, separating the skull base into Ant and post halves,
  • Occurs Severe Force to side of head (e.g. in motorcycle accidents).
  • Such fractures are commonly associated with injuries of the brain stem, especially pontomedullary tears.

questions.text: Identify the ‘1’ in the picture: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystoid Macular Edema

 

  • Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centred around the fovea with the formation of tiny cyst-like cavities forming a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography.
  • CME develops due to leakage of fluid following breakdown of inner blood-retinal barrier (i.e., leakage from the retinal capillaries).
  • It is associated with a number of disorders, including postoperative complications following cataract extraction and penetrating keratoplasty, retinal vascular disorders (e.g., diabetic retinopathy and central retinal vein occlusion), intraocular inflammations (e.g., pars planitis, posterior uveitis, Behcet disease), side effects of drugs (e.g., following use of adrenaline eyedrops, especially for aphakic glaucoma, and retinal dystrophies (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa).
  • Clinical manifestations of CME include visual loss, which may be initially minimal to moderate and un-associated with other symptoms, but can progress to permanent decrease in vision if edema persists.
  • CME is best examined with a fundus contact lens on slit-lamp or +90D lens, and typically presents a "Honey-comb appearance" of macula due to multiple cystoid oval spaces on ophthalmoscopy.

 

 

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography demonstrates leakage and accumulation of dye in the macular region, which in a well-established case presents a "flower petal appearance".

 

 

Cystoid macular edema (CME) and central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) are two conditions that can affect the macula, the central part of the retina. Here is a table comparing the two conditions:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macular Hole: This would appear as a dark or black spot in the center of the macula due to a full-thickness opening in the retina, which is not observed in this image.

 

Option C. Smoke stack pattern: This pattern would be typical of central serous chorioretinopathy and is characterized by a well-defined, localized leakage point causing fluid to ascend vertically, not seen here.

 

Option D. Age related Macular Degeneration: Typically shows drusen, geographic atrophy, or neovascularization, none of which are evident in this fluorescein angiography image as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME) often presents with a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography due to pooling of dye in cystic spaces of the macula and is associated with various underlying conditions affecting the vascular integrity of the retina.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sodium nitroprusside? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stimulation of guanylyl cyclase
