Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator that works by stimulating guanylyl cyclase. When sodium nitroprusside enters the bloodstream, it rapidly releases nitric oxide (NO). This NO then activates guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells. The activation of guanylyl cyclase increases the conversion of GTP to cyclic GMP (cGMP). Elevated levels of cGMP lead to the dephosphorylation of myosin light chains, resulting in relaxation of vascular smooth muscle and subsequent vasodilation. This mechanism effectively reduces blood pressure and is used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and severe heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased cAMP: Drugs that increase cAMP, such as beta-adrenergic agonists, work through different mechanisms involving the activation of adenylate cyclase, not guanylyl cyclase. cAMP primarily mediates actions like increased heart rate and bronchodilation, which is not the primary action of sodium nitroprusside.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockage: Calcium channel blockers, such as verapamil and diltiazem, inhibit the influx of calcium ions into cardiac and smooth muscle cells, leading to muscle relaxation and vasodilation. Sodium nitroprusside does not act through this pathway.

 

Option D. K+ channel opener: Potassium channel openers, such as minoxidil, work by hyperpolarizing the cell membrane, leading to relaxation of vascular smooth muscle. This is not the mechanism of action of sodium nitroprusside.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium nitroprusside acts by stimulating guanylyl cyclase, which leads to an increase in cGMP, causing relaxation of vascular smooth muscle and vasodilation. This makes it effective in rapidly reducing blood pressure in hypertensive emergencies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the emergency with a BP of 160/100 mg and a heart rate of 120 bpm. CECT done reveals a Stanford type A aortic dissection. What is the initial management of this given condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta blocker medication

 

Beta-blockers are used to control the heart rate and blood pressure in patients with aortic dissection. This helps in reducing the sheer force exerted on the wall of the aorta, which may help in preventing the progression of the dissection. Beta-blockers are the first-line medication for heart rate and blood pressure control in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin): This is an anticoagulant used to prevent or treat blood clots. In the context of an aortic dissection, it's not the initial management as it might increase the risk of bleeding within the dissection.

 

Option C. Surgical repair: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A (DeBakey type I and II) ascending aortic dissection. However, before surgery, it is crucial to stabilize the patient's vital signs, and beta-blockers play a significant role in this aspect.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibitors: These are anticoagulants that act by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Like LMWH, they are not the initial management for aortic dissection due to the potential risk of bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is Beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The Preferred Beta-blocker drug is Esmolol.

 

Once hypertension is controlled, then definitive repair of aortic dissection is done based on Stanford type.

 

Stanford Classification:

 

  • Type A: This type involves the ascending aorta and possibly the descending aorta. It is considered the more dangerous type and often requires emergency surgery. Given its involvement with the ascending aorta, it's critical to manage promptly to avoid complications such as rupture or impairment of blood flow to vital organs.
  • Type B: Involves only the descending aorta.

 

Symptoms:

 

  • Severe, sudden, tearing chest pain
  • Pain that radiates to the back/scapula
  • Shortness of breath
  • Sweating
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body (in rare cases)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Medical Management: Medications, especially beta-blockers, are often given initially to lower heart rate and blood pressure, reducing the force of blood against the aortic walls and potentially preventing further tearing.
  • Surgical Intervention: Emergency surgical correction is the preferred treatment for Stanford type A dissections. The surgery aims to repair the damaged section of the aorta and to prevent rupture or further dissection. Endovascular repair is preferred for Stanford B.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammasome

 

Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Inflammasomes are large cytosolic multiprotein complexes that assemble in response to detection of infection- or stress-associated stimuli and lead to the activation of caspase-1-mediated inflammatory responses, including cleavage and unconventional secretion of the leaderless proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, and initiation of an inflammatory form of cell death referred to as pyroptosis.

 

Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for killing of infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

 

  • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells
  • This causes activation of caspase-1
  • This results in generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toll-like receptors (TLRs): Toll-like receptors are pattern recognition receptors that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and play a significant role in initiating the innate immune response. However, they are not directly involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option C. P selectin: P selectin is a cell adhesion molecule found on the surface of activated endothelial cells and platelets. It mediates the initial interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells during inflammation, but it is not involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option D. Manoreceptor: This appears to be a typographical error, possibly meant to refer to the mannose receptor. The mannose receptor is involved in recognizing microbial sugars and is part of the immune system's response to pathogens. However, it is not involved in the clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammasomes are crucial in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells by activating caspase-1 and inducing the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as triggering pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

 

The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

 

Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. This technique allows for a presumptive diagnosis of syphilis even before antibodies have developed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Phase contrast microscopy:

 

  • Phase contrast microscopy enhances the contrast of transparent specimens without staining. It is often used for live cells and other transparent samples.
  • The background in phase contrast microscopy is not typically as dark as in darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscopy

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorophores to stain specific structures, which then emit light when exposed to specific wavelengths. The images typically show bright fluorescent colors against a dark background.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy

 

  • Electron microscopy uses a beam of electrons to create an image. The images produced are typically in black and white with extremely high resolution, showing detailed structures at the nanoscale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

choices.text: Total blood count with peripheral smear

questions.text: A 53-year-old patient was admitted complains of dyspnea. On examination he has puffy face, with engorged veins over the chest. SVC obstruction is suspected. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal enlargement. What is the next step? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CT thorax

 

Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction, suggested by symptoms like dyspnea, facial puffiness, and engorged chest veins, along with a chest X-ray showing mediastinal enlargement, requires further detailed imaging to accurately assess the extent of the obstruction and the presence of any mediastinal masses. A CT scan of the thorax is the most appropriate next step as it provides detailed images of the chest's anatomy, helping to identify the cause of the SVC obstruction, which is crucial for planning appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total blood count with peripheral smear: While useful for general health assessments and diagnosing blood disorders, this does not directly address the structural issues seen in SVC obstruction.

 

Option C. Start cyclophosphamide: Beginning chemotherapy like cyclophosphamide would only be appropriate after a specific diagnosis of a malignancy causing the SVC obstruction, confirmed via imaging and biopsy.

 

Option D. Urgent referral to RT: Referral for radiation therapy (RT) may be necessary if a malignancy is confirmed, but it is premature without a detailed thoracic CT and biopsy if indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT thorax is critical for detailed evaluation in suspected SVC obstruction to confirm the diagnosis and guide further specific treatment, whether surgical, medical, or radiation therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ascending thick loop of Henle

 

The thick ascending limb has a sodium hydrogen counter-transport mechanism in its luminal

cell membrane that mediates sodium reabsorption and hydrogen secretion in this segment.

 

The thick segment of the ascending loop of Henle is virtually impermeable to water.
 

Therefore, most of the water delivered to this segment remains in the tubule, despite reabsorption of large amounts of solute. The tubular fluid in the ascending limb becomes very dilute as it flows toward the distal tubule. Hence it is called the diluting segment of the kidney.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The PCT is primarily involved in reabsorbing water, sodium, and other solutes, but it is not considered the diluting segment.

 

Option B. Collecting duct: Incorrect. The collecting duct is involved in the reabsorption of water and solutes and is influenced by hormones like ADH, but it is not the primary diluting segment.

 

Option D. Descending loop of Henle: Incorrect. The descending loop of Henle is permeable to water but not to solutes, making it responsible for concentrating the tubular fluid, not diluting it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle is the diluting segment of the kidney due to its impermeability to water and active reabsorption of solutes

questions.text: Child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which among the following accumulates in brain in this condition? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Long chain fatty acid

 

Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA). Peroxisomal enzymes are produced; but their entry into peroxisome is denied. This leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA. Accumulation of VLCFA in CNS causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose: Accumulation of glucose is associated with disorders like diabetes, not Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option B. Lactic acid: Accumulation of lactic acid is seen in lactic acidosis and mitochondrial disorders, but not specifically in Zellweger syndrome.

 

Option D. Triglycerides: While triglycerides are stored fats, their accumulation is not the primary issue in Zellweger syndrome. The critical problem is the accumulation of VLCFA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome leads to the accumulation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) in the brain due to defective peroxisomal oxidation, resulting in severe neurological impairments and early childhood death.

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the primary concern addressed by the POCSO Act? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Child sexual abuse

 

  • The POCSO Act (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012 is designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • It includes provisions for punishment of various offenses such as penetrative sexual assault, aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, aggravated sexual assault, sexual harassment, and the use of children for pornography.
  • The act ensures stringent punishment for offenders to provide a safe and secure environment for children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Women empowerment: Incorrect. The POCSO Act is focused on protecting children from sexual offenses, not specifically on women empowerment.

 

Option B. Human trafficking: Incorrect. While important, human trafficking is not the primary focus of the POCSO Act.

 

Option C. Juvenile delinquency: Incorrect. The act deals with protecting children from sexual offenses, not addressing juvenile delinquency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO Act (Prevention of Children from Sexual Offences Act) 2012

 

  • Child definition: Any person less than 18 years of age
  • Includes: Sexual abuses and pornography
  • Punishments under the act:

questions.text: A young donor came to the blood bank for the first time for platelet apheresis with platelet count of 1.9L. During the course he developed paraesthesia and circumoral numbness during donation. His vitals remained stable though. ECG showed tachycardia with ST-T changes. What is the reason for his symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypocalcemia

 

Hypocalcemia occurs due to citrate. It is due to calcium binding citrate anticoagulant used to keep blood from clotting in apheresis machine.

 

Treatment for this would be to slow down the flow of device and/or giving oral calcium supplements.

 

IV calcium is only required in case of prolonged apheresis as in case of HPC collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypovolemic Shock: This would be characterized by low blood pressure and signs of systemic shock, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Seizures: Although severe hypocalcemia can lead to seizures, the description focuses on paraesthesia and numbness, common early signs of hypocalcemia, without any mention of convulsive activity.

 

Option D. Allergic Reaction: The symptoms listed are not typical of allergic reactions, which might include hives, itching, or respiratory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During platelet apheresis, monitoring for symptoms of hypocalcemia is crucial due to the use of citrate. Symptoms such as tingling, numbness, and ECG changes warrant immediate evaluation and management, typically with calcium supplementation to counteract the effects of citrate.

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for a period of 6 months, measuring 2 cm x 3 cm. No lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. How do you manage this case? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has a midline lesion on the labia majora, which indicates that the lesion is close to or crossing the midline. In cases of midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline, bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is necessary along with radical vulvectomy. This approach ensures that all potential pathways of lymphatic spread are adequately addressed.

 

New (2021) FIGO staging for carcinoma of the vulva:

 

  • Tumors 2 cm or less in size with 1 mm or less invasion: Treated by wide local excision.
  • Tumors more than 2 cm with more than 1 mm depth of invasion: Treated by modified radical vulvectomy with groin lymph node dissection.
  • LN dissection through separate incision: Lymph node dissection should be inguino-femoral.
  • Bilateral lymph node dissection: Performed for midline lesions and those within 2 cm of the midline.
  • Unilateral dissection: If the lesion is unilateral and ipsilateral nodes are negative, bilateral dissection is not necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection: This would be appropriate for unilateral lesions with no evidence of contralateral spread, but not for midline lesions.

 

Option C. Simple vulvectomy: Simple vulvectomy is not sufficient for managing invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a lesion size of 2 cm x 3 cm and potential for deeper invasion.

 

Option D. Chemoradiation with resection: Chemoradiation followed by resection is typically reserved for advanced or inoperable cases, or where there is a need to downstage the tumor before surgery. This case can be managed surgically given the size and lack of palpable lymph nodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For midline lesions or lesions within 2 cm of the midline in squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection is the appropriate management.

 

Ref: FIGO staging of CA vulva, Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1436, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 484-485.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from a rural area of Bihar presents to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in Patna. He has been experiencing fever for the past week, associated with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and palpable lymphadenopathy. Despite being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antimalarial agents by a local practitioner, there's been no significant relief. Blood investigations for typhoid (Widal test) are negative; however, the rk39 dipstick test is positive. Based on the clinical picture and the diagnostic findings, what would be the most appropriate drug of choice for the treatment of his condition? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liposomal Amphotericin B

 

  • This clinical presentation strongly indicates the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of action for this patient involves the administration of liposomal amphotericin B.

 

 

Incubation Period: 10 days to 2 years (average 1 – 4 months)

 

Serological tests:

 

  • ELISA: for diagnosis as well as epidemiological field survey
  • rk 39 dipstick test
  • Indirect Flourescent Antibody Test (IFAT)
  • Direct Agglutination Test

 

 Treatment of Leishmaniasis

 

  • Sodium stibogluconate
  • Miltefosine
  • Paramomycin
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (DOC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fluconazole is an anti-fungal, not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

 

Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA

 

Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.

questions.text:
A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination, he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. Most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Opening pressure- increased
  • Proteins- mildly increased
  • Glucose – normal
  • Lymphocytes- increased
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coxsackie

 

The CSF findings indicative of increased lymphocytes, normal glucose levels, and mildly increased protein are characteristic of viral meningitis. Coxsackie virus, a common cause of viral meningitis, often presents with these CSF findings. The typical profile of viral meningitis includes normal glucose levels, which helps differentiate it from bacterial, fungal, and tuberculous meningitis where glucose levels are often decreased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: Tuberculous meningitis typically shows low glucose, high protein, and a mixed cellular response in the CSF, which does not match the patient's CSF profile.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhea: Generally causes bacterial meningitis with a different CSF profile—low glucose, high protein, and predominantly polymorphonuclear cells.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Fungal meningitis also shows low glucose and is not consistent with the normal glucose levels observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes
Clear colorless to pale yellow

questions.text: Which of the following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear colorless to pale yellow

 

Explanation:

 

The color of normal amniotic fluid varies during pregnancy and can indicate different conditions:

 

  • In early pregnancy: The amniotic fluid is colorless.
  • Near term: It becomes straw-colored.
  • Deep yellow/golden color: This can indicate fetal anemia.
  • Green (meconium-stained): Indicates fetal distress or post-maturity.
  • Red: Suggests abruption.
  • Dark colored/tobacco-like: Indicates fetal demise.

 

Normal amniotic fluid should be clear, colorless, or pale yellow, especially in the earlier stages of pregnancy and near term when the fluid changes to a straw color.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Milky to yellowish green with mucus flakes: This description is not characteristic of normal amniotic fluid. Such a color can indicate the presence of infection or contamination.

 

Option B. Amber colored: Amber-colored amniotic fluid is not a normal finding and may indicate complications such as the presence of blood or other abnormalities.

 

Option D. Golden color: Golden-colored amniotic fluid typically indicates fetal anemia, which is a pathological condition and not a feature of normal amniotic fluid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal amniotic fluid is clear, colorless to pale yellow, changing to straw-colored near term.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 43, William’s text book of obstetrics 24th edition pg 298

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed a normal uterus, but gonads weren't detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Swyer's syndrome

 

The clinical scenario described is indicative of Swyer syndrome, which is characterized by a 46XY karyotype and gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Key points about Swyer syndrome:

 

  • Swyer syndrome, also known as 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, is a condition where individuals with an XY karyotype present phenotypically as females.
  • These patients have a normal uterus and vagina but lack functioning gonads, which are often termed "streak gonads."
  • Because of gonadal dysgenesis, these individuals do not secrete testosterone or Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), leading to the development of female genital organs and phenotype.
  • Clinical presentation includes primary amenorrhea, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, and female external genitalia despite a 46XY karyotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Also known as testicular feminization syndrome, individuals have a 46XY karyotype but are phenotypically female with well-developed breasts and absent axillary and pubic hair. The gonads are testes, and there is no uterus.

 

Option B. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45XO karyotype. Patients typically present with short stature, shield chest, cubitus valgus, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and streak ovaries.

 

Option C. True hermaphrodite: True hermaphrodites have both ovarian and testicular tissue present, which is not consistent with the clinical scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis) is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype present phenotypically as females with primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and a normal uterus but lack functioning gonads.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 33446, Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg373

choices.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy

questions.text: Identify this condition? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic placenta, characterized by a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both a chorion and an amniotic sac. This type of twinning occurs when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation, after the formation of the trophoblast, leading to a monochorionic condition.

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestations have a high fetal death rate due to several complications:

 

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

 

The best time for delivery of monochorionic monoamniotic twins is between 32-34 weeks via Caesarean section.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome: This is a complication seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies. It involves a donor twin and a recipient twin. The donor twin is anemic, growth-restricted, and has oligohydramnios, while the recipient twin is polycythemic, has polyhydramnios, and suffers from circulatory overload.

 

Option B. Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In this type of pregnancy, there are two amniotic cavities and one chorion. This occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 4-7 days of gestation.

 

Option D. Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy: This pregnancy type involves two amniotic cavities and two chorions. It occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 0-3 days of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies involve a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane, occurring when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 233-234,

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Amniotic fluid index determination

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the labor room? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a procedure called Cardiotocography (CTG). CTG is a method used to monitor the fetal heart rate (FHR) and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. It helps assess the well-being of the fetus and identify any signs of fetal distress.

 

Key points about Cardiotocography (CTG):

 

  • If done antenatally (when the patient is not in labor), it is called a Non-Stress Test (NST).
  • During labor, CTG is used to continuously monitor the fetal heart rate and contractions to ensure the fetus is not in distress.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure in which a sample of amniotic fluid is aspirated for prenatal diagnosis or therapeutic purposes. This is not the procedure shown in the image.

 

Option B. MCA Doppler: MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery) Doppler is performed to assess fetal growth restriction and fetal anemia. It is an ultrasound procedure and does not match the image shown.

 

Option D. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI): AFI is an ultrasound estimation of amniotic fluid volume. It is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiotocography (CTG) is used to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor. When performed antenatally without labor, it is referred to as a Non-Stress Test (NST).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg339, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg122

questions.text: A patient with AIDS was treated with zidovudine, lamivudine, indinavir, ketoconazole and cotrimoxazole. He developed nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia and insulin resistance. Which of the drugs could have been the cause? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indinavir

 

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is known for several side effects, which include nephrolithiasis (kidney stones), central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance. These adverse effects are part of the metabolic complications often associated with protease inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is an antifungal agent that does not typically cause nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects are more related to hepatotoxicity, adrenal insufficiency, and drug interactions due to CYP3A4 inhibition.

 

Option C. Lamivudine: Lamivudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. It is not commonly associated with nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, or insulin resistance. Its side effects can include lactic acidosis and hepatic steatosis, but these are less common.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Zidovudine, another NRTI, is associated with side effects such as anemia, neutropenia, and myopathy but not with the specific metabolic complications listed (nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indinavir, a protease inhibitor used in HIV/AIDS treatment, is the drug responsible for causing nephrolithiasis, central obesity, hyperlipidemia, and insulin resistance among the medications listed.

questions.text: During your residency, you learn about a specific protocol essential for physicians when dealing with challenging scenarios. This protocol, known as the SPIKES protocol, serves a unique purpose in medical communication. Can you identify the primary objective of employing the SPIKES protocol? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breaking bad news

 

SPIKES PROTOCOL

 

  • Communication of cancer Diagnosis & Prognosis (or any adverse outcome)
  • Protocol of 6 steps

S - Set up interview

P - Perceptions

I - Invitation to explain

K - Knowledge

E - Emotions

S - Summary & Strategy

 

Best used for Communication of diagnosis and prognosis for Breast Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triage: Incorrect. Triage involves prioritizing patient care based on the severity of their condition.

 

Option B. Consent for study participation: Incorrect. Obtaining consent for study participation requires a different communication protocol focused on informed consent.

 

Option C. Hospital infection control: Incorrect. Infection control involves protocols for preventing and managing infections within the hospital setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SPIKES protocol is specifically designed to guide physicians in breaking bad news to patients, ensuring the communication is handled with sensitivity and clarity.

choices.text: Central capillary dilatation → Wheal → Surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare.

questions.text: On performing a Histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare

 

In patient with brachial plexus trunk injury, there is anesthesia over the skin in that region. Histamine test in this patient will result in capillary dilatation and wheal without surrounding flare.

 

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin which includes a red reaction, flare and wheal.

 

  • Red reaction is because of capillary dilatation and is independent of innervation.
  • Flare reaction is due to dilatation of arterioles caused by the axon reflex.
  • Axon reflex or antidromic reflex is the process by which the impulses are conducted in a direction opposite to the normal direction. Normally, the impulses produced by a cutaneous pain receptor pass through sensory nerve fiber towards the nerve cell body in posterior nerve root ganglion. Some of these impulses pass through the other branches of the same fiber in the opposite direction and reach the blood vessels supplied by these branches. Impulses now dilate the blood vessels. This is called the antidromic or axon reflex. Thus, flare is absent in anesthetized skin.
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to increased capillary permeability

 

The triple response can be seen after total sympathectomy

 

The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a brachial plexus trunk injury, the histamine test will result in central capillary dilatation and a wheal without the surrounding flare due to the disruption of the axon reflex.

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.

 

Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve and Option C. Ulnar nerve are less frequently chosen for biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy due to their mixed sensory and motor functions, which could lead to functional deficits if damaged.

 

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve also known as the common peroneal nerve, is generally avoided in routine nerve biopsies for leprosy due to its deeper location and the significant motor components it controls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.11 28.14

Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotretinoin


The presence of multiple nodulocystic lesions suggests a diagnosis of severe acne, specifically nodular acne or acne conglobata. Isotretinoin is the first-line drug for treating severe acne due to its effectiveness in reducing sebaceous gland size, decreasing sebum production, and minimizing inflammation.

 

Key considerations when using isotretinoin:

 

  • Teratogenicity: Isotretinoin is highly teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women, women planning to become pregnant, and breastfeeding mothers.
  • Pregnancy Testing: For females of childbearing age, two negative pregnancy tests are required before starting isotretinoin. Monthly pregnancy tests should be performed during treatment.
  • Baseline and Ongoing Monitoring: Baseline serum lipids, liver enzymes (transaminases), and complete blood counts should be obtained before initiating isotretinoin. These tests should be monitored monthly for the first 3-6 months and then once every 3 months.

 

For acitretin (a systemic retinoid used in cutaneous psoriasis), female patients should avoid conception for at least 3 years after discontinuing treatment due to its long half-life and potential teratogenicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroids:  Systemic steroids are not the primary treatment for nodulocystic acne and are typically reserved for specific inflammatory conditions.

 

Option C. Erythromycin:  Erythromycin is used in acne treatment, especially in mild to moderate cases, but it is not the drug of choice for severe nodulocystic acne.

 

Option D. Tetracycline:  Tetracyclines, like doxycycline or minocycline, can be used for moderate to severe acne but are generally less effective than isotretinoin for nodulocystic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotretinoin is the first-line treatment for severe nodulocystic acne due to its efficacy in reducing sebaceous gland activity and inflammation, but it requires careful monitoring due to its teratogenic effects and impact on serum lipids and liver enzymes.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Episiotomy scissors

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument given in the picture is an episiotomy scissors.
  • The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.
  • An episiotomy is NOT given routinely.
  • It’s use is restricted and is given in situations like.
    • Macrosomia
    • After coming head of breech
    • Instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Curved artery: It has serrated tips and ratchet lock . It is used to clamp blood vessels, hold peritoneal edges, tissue dissection

 

 

Option C. Curved mayo scissors: These are used to cut tissue such as the uterus, rectus sheath etc.

 

 

Option D. Mosquito forceps: It is a small artery forceps used to catch small bleeders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed with an angulated blade to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins, thereby reducing the risk of obstetric anal sphincter injuries and complete perineal tears during childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 755

questions.text: The image shows two data distribution curves from separate studies within the same population: one depicted with a red line and the other with a blue line. Given the graphical representation, which of the following correctly represents the relationship among the mean, median, and mode for the data presented? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mean = median, not equal to mode

 

Analyzing the two graphs, we observe different distribution patterns:

 

  • Red line (Study A): The distribution is unimodal and symmetrical, indicating that the mean, median, and mode are all equal.
  • Blue line (Study B): The distribution is bimodal, showing two distinct peaks. In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median are typically equal, but there are two modes, making the mode not equal to the mean or median.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a bimodal distribution, the mean and median can be equal, but the mode will not be equal to them, as there are two modes.

questions.text: Identify the procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myelography

 

Explanation:

 

The procedure shows contrast within the subarachnoid space in myelography.

 

  • Expansion of the contrast-filled space in myelography is seen in intradural extramedullary tumors.
  • In myelography, contrast is injected into the CS space, and if a tumor is present in the intradural extramedullary space, it causes the CS space on that side to widen.
  • Neurofibroma and meningioma are two examples of such lesions and on myelography with the contrast column, these lesions will also have a meniscus-like appearance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiography: Involves the injection of contrast material into blood vessels and is used primarily to examine vascular structures, not visible in this image.

 

Option C. DEXA: Stands for Dual Energy X-ray Absorptiometry, a method used to measure bone density, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Projectional radiography: Refers to standard X-ray imaging without contrast enhancement, whereas this procedure clearly involves contrast material within the spinal canal.

 

Educational Objective:


Myelography is an essential diagnostic tool for visualizing the spinal subarachnoid space and identifying pathologies that may impact the spinal cord and nerve roots, providing crucial information that cannot be obtained through standard X-rays alone.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 822

questions.text: What is the adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atropine Sulfate eye ointment

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as the nonspecific supportive treatment in both bacterial as well as a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is utilized in the management of fungal corneal ulcers primarily to relieve symptoms like pain due to ciliary spasm and to prevent complications such as the formation of posterior synechiae. Atropine achieves this by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscles, thus providing a therapeutic benefit in the treatment of corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine e/d: Generally used to contract the pupil in glaucoma treatment, not appropriate for corneal ulcers as it can increase pain by causing ciliary spasm.

 

Option B. Lignocaine e/d: An anesthetic used for temporary pain relief but does not serve as adjuvant therapy in managing ulcers.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone e/d: A corticosteroid, generally avoided in fungal infections due to its potential to exacerbate infections by suppressing immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine sulfate eye ointment is used as adjuvant therapy in fungal corneal ulcers to relieve pain and prevent the formation of posterior synechiae by dilating the pupil and paralyzing the ciliary muscle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontal

 

The frontal lobe is responsible for executive functions, social behavior, motivation, and impulse control. Damage to the frontal lobe can result in disinhibited behaviors, such as socially inappropriate actions (e.g., urinating in public without remorse), lack of motivation (apathy), and mild memory impairments. These changes are often seen in conditions affecting the frontal lobe, including frontal lobe syndrome or neurodegenerative diseases. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parietal Lobe: Primarily responsible for sensation and spatial processing. Lesions here might manifest as sensory deficits or spatial disorientation, rather than the behavioral issues described.

 

Option B. Occipital Lobe: Concerned with vision. Deficits or lesions here primarily manifest as visual disturbances, not behavioral or motivational issues.

 

Option D. Temporal Lobe: Associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion. Although it does play a role in memory, the other symptoms described are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Frontal Lobe is involved in executive functions, decision-making, motivation, and socially appropriate behavior. Damage can lead to disinhibited behavior, apathy, and memory deficits.

 

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 346-348.

questions.text: Low apparent volume of distribution of drug indicates?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Not extensively distributed to tissues

 

Apparent Volume of distribution (Vd) = dose administered I.V/ plasma concentration It indicates how extensively the drug is distributed in the tissues. For example, Chloroquine has the highest volume of distribution, as it is mostly distributed to the liver and a very small amount is left for the action on RBC.

 

E.g.: If a 1000 mg of drug A is given i.v (100% bioavailability) and the plasma concentration reached is 10 mg/ liter then the apparent volume of distribution (Vd) is 1000/10= 10 liters.

 

But the normal blood volume is about 5 liters. A high Vd is due to accumulation of drug A being distributed in extravascular tissues resulting in low plasma concentration.

 

Half-life or t1/2 relationship with volume of distribution (Vd) and clearance (CI) is given by the formula t 1/2 = 0.693 × Vd /CI. t1/2 is directly proportional to Vd but it is also inversely proportional to clearance. If a drug has a low volume of distribution but clearance is very low, t1/2 can still be high. So low Vd doesn't always imply low t1/2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low t 1/2: The half-life (t1/2) of a drug is influenced by both its volume of distribution (Vd) and its clearance (Cl). It is given by the formula:

 

t1/2=0.693×Vd/Cl

 

A low Vd does not necessarily imply a low half-life, as the half-life is also dependent on the clearance of the drug. If the clearance is low, the half-life can still be long despite a low Vd.

 

Option B. Low bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of an administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form. It is primarily affected by the route of administration and first-pass metabolism, not by the volume of distribution.

 

Option C. Low efficacy: Efficacy refers to the ability of a drug to produce a desired therapeutic effect. It is determined by the drug’s mechanism of action and intrinsic activity at its target receptors, not by its volume of distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A low apparent volume of distribution (Vd) indicates that the drug is not extensively distributed to tissues and remains largely confined to the blood plasma. This parameter is essential for understanding the pharmacokinetic behavior of the drug in the body.

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abrasion

 

The given image shows the superficial injury and is not penetrating the full thickness of the epidermis, bleeding is also not seen, all these indicates towards abrasion.

 

Abrasion

 

  • Abrasions are superficial injuries of the skin and visceral linings in the body, resulting in a break in the continuity of tissue.
  • It does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.
  • Only epidermis (mostly partial epidermis) is involved.
  • No bleeding.
  • No scar formation.
  • All abrasions are simple hurt except corneal abrasions (impairs vision and hence a grievous hurt).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laceration is a deep wound produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged.

 

Option C. Bruise is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues. It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Option D. Imprint or impact abrasion happens when large force is applied over lesser period of time, also results in crushing epithelium eg.: Tyre mark, recoil abrasion, radiator grill mark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abrasions are superficial injuries involving only the epidermis, with no bleeding and no scar formation, and are typically simple hurts except for corneal abrasions.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not a common ocular manifestation of dengue infection.
  • Dengue infection can have various manifestations in different organ systems, primarily characterized by inflammation and bleeding.
  • Until recently, eye involvement was not recognized as a common feature of dengue infection, apart from retro-orbital pain.
  • The potential pathogenic mechanisms for dengue-related eye involvement may include direct viral effects on the eye, immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subconjunctival hemorrhage: Common in dengue due to increased fragility of blood vessels and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Uveitis: While less common, uveitis can occur in dengue fever as part of a systemic immune response to the infection.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: This is a direct consequence of the hemorrhagic tendency in dengue fever, related to thrombocytopenia and vascular fragility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

 

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis.
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical parameter used to evaluate maternal health within countries. In the context of public health statistics, how is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for a country conventionally expressed? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, providing a measure of the safety and quality of maternal care in a country.

questions.text: A rape victim is brought to the casualty of a government hospital for examination. Within what time should a vaginal swab be taken to look for the presence of spermatozoa? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 72 hours

 

Spermatozoa can be demonstrated only if a vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours of an assault.

 

Semen can be demonstrated on evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing upto 96 hours.

 

Educational Objective

 

Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms

 

•Spermatozoa remain motile in the vagina for 6-8 hours, occasionally up to 12 hours.

•Nonmotile forms can be detected for about 24 hours, rarely up to 48-72 hours.

•Detection involves aspirating vaginal contents and examining under a microscope.

•Motile sperms suggest recent intercourse; nonmotile sperms indicate a broader time frame (12-72 hours).

•Intact spermatozoa are rarely found in the vagina after 72 hours.

•Seminal fluid detection from vasectomized males requires prostatic acid phosphatase demonstration.

•P30, a semen-specific glycoprotein, is used as a screening test, detectable in vaginal fluid for about 27 hours.

questions.text: Identify the site which is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Periaqueductal gray

 

The analgesia system consists of three major components:

 

(1) The periaqueductal gray and periventricular areas of the mesencephalon and upper pons surround the aqueduct of Sylvius and portions of the third and fourth ventricles. Neurons from these areas send signals to  

 

(2) the raphe magnus nucleus, a thin midline nucleus located in the lower pons and upper medulla, and the nucleus reticularis paragigantocellularis, located laterally in the medulla. From these nuclei, second-order signals are transmitted down the dorsolateral columns in the spinal cord to

 

(3) a pain inhibitory complex located in the dorsal horns of the spinal cord. At this point, the analgesia signals can block the pain before it is relayed to the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticospinal tract: Incorrect. This tract is involved in motor control and voluntary movements, not pain relief.

 

Option C. Medial lemniscus: Incorrect. This pathway carries sensory information related to touch, vibration, and proprioception, not pain relief.

 

Option D. Medial longitudinal fasciculus: Incorrect. This bundle of nerve fibers coordinates eye movements and helps maintain balance, not pain relief.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a critical component of the analgesia system, responsible for relieving pain by sending inhibitory signals to block pain transmission in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5'-3' Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3′ to 5′ and 5′ to 3′ exonuclease activities. When 5′ to 3′ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

Details of DNA Polymerase I and Klenow Fragment:

  • DNA Polymerase I (Kornberg's enzyme): This enzyme has three activities:
    • 5'->3' polymerase activity (synthesizes DNA)
    • 3'-5' exonuclease activity (proofreading)
    • 5'-3' exonuclease activity (removes RNA primers and repairs DNA)

  • Klenow Fragment: This fragment results from removing the 5'-3' exonuclease domain. It retains:

     

The Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology due to its ability to synthesize DNA and proofread without degrading the DNA template or newly synthesized strand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3'-5' Exonuclease: This proofreading activity is retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option C. 5'->3' DNA polymerase: This polymerization activity is also retained by the Klenow fragment.

 

Option D. 3'-5' DNA polymerase: This option is incorrect terminology; which is correctly termed 3'-5' exonuclease and is retained in the Klenow fragment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I lacks the 5'-3' exonuclease activity but retains the 5'->3' polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities, making it useful for DNA synthesis and recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most conspicuous sign of breast cancer?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Peaud'orange

 

Explanation:

 

The most conspicuous sign of breast cancer is Peau d' orange appearance.

 

Peaud'orange (orange peel like texture), is the edematous swollen and pitted breast skin due to obstruction of the subcutaneous lymphatics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nipple retraction: Nipple retraction, or inversion, is another potential sign of breast cancer. In some cases, a cancerous lump or tumor can pull on the tissues surrounding the nipple, causing it to retract or appear inverted. However, nipple retraction can also be a benign condition and may not always indicate breast cancer.

 

Option C. Puckering: Puckering of the breast skin can occur when there is an underlying mass or tumor. This may cause changes in the normal contours of the breast, leading to visible puckering or dimpling. Like nipple retraction, puckering can result from both cancerous and non-cancerous breast conditions.

 

Option D. Both nipple retraction and puckering: Some individuals may present with both nipple retraction and puckering as signs of breast cancer. These signs may indicate the presence of a tumor or mass within the breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peau d'orange term refers to the "orange peel" appearance of the skin on the breast. It is characterized by dimpling or thickening of the skin that resembles the texture of an orange peel.

 

Peau d'orange can be a sign of advanced breast cancer. It occurs when cancer cells block the lymphatic channels in the breast, causing the skin to pucker and become swollen. While it is a significant sign of breast cancer, it typically indicates a more advanced stage of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

 

Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

 

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

 

  • Dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giardia: Is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. BUT does not release mucus in stool.

 

Option C. Campylobacter: Presents with fever, pain and watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica infection presents with dysentery, characterized by stools containing mucus and blood, along with abdominal pain.

questions.text: A patient alleges negligence by a surgeon and sues him for the same. In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3 days

 

In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within 72 hours/ 3 days.

 

The treating doctor has to maintain the medical records of the patients for a period of three years as per the regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEDICAL RECORDS

 

1. Duration of retention of records –

  • Digital Records – 10 years
  • Hard copy – 
  • OPD patients: 3 years
  • Indoor patients: 3 years
  • MLC: 10 years

2. Time to provide records – 3 days

3. What if records not maintained – punished for infamous conduct

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of morphine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acute myocardial infarction

 

Explanation:

 

Acute myocardial infarction: Morphine is often used in the setting of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) to relieve pain and anxiety. It also has the beneficial effect of reducing preload and afterload on the heart, which can decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This makes it beneficial in the management of AMI. It's not a contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Morphine can induce histamine release, which may lead to bronchospasm. In patients with bronchial asthma, this bronchospasm can exacerbate respiratory difficulties, making morphine potentially dangerous for these patients.

 

Option B. Renal failure: Morphine is metabolized in the liver and its metabolites, especially morphine-6-glucuronide, are excreted by the kidneys. In the case of renal failure, these active metabolites can accumulate, leading to prolonged and potentially toxic effects.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Morphine has a depressive effect on the respiratory center in the brain, leading to respiratory depression. In patients with emphysema, a condition already characterized by compromised respiratory function, morphine can exacerbate respiratory difficulties and decrease the drive to breathe.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Morphine is beneficial and not contraindicated in the management of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) as it helps to relieve pain, reduce anxiety, and decrease myocardial oxygen demand.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) usually dislodged from the utricle. These otoconia will enter the semicircular canal and will cause change in the density of the endolymphatic fluid as well as they will inadvertently touch the cupula and cause unnecessary stimulation of the hair cells in cristae.
  • Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the utricle from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: Presents with recurrent spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting for hours associated by aural fullness, tinnitus and hearing loss.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Presents with severe, sudden-onset, spontaneous vertigo which is continuous and associated with hearing loss, nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Syncope is defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness with an inability to maintain postural tone that is followed by spontaneous recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinging on: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Patients complain of a clunking during knee extension, caused by a suprapatellar fibrous nodule that interferes with patella movement.
  • There is an accumulation of scar tissue along the undersurface of the quadriceps tendon, proximal to the superior pole of the patella.
  • The cause of scar tissue is unknown, but may be related to:
    • Direct trauma to quadriceps tendon during patella resection during TKR
    • Impingement of the quadriceps tendon on the femoral component due to an undersized patellar component
  • Scar is entrapped within the intercondylar notch during flexion.
  • It impinges on the femoral component and is forced out of the notch during active knee extension.
  • The painful snap or clunk is usually felt between 30-45 degrees
  • Many patients can be managed without surgery.
  • However, if there are persistent symptoms, surgical excision of the nodule can be useful.

 

OTHER SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS

 

  • Irritation of the lateral facet of the patella: Contact between the lateral facet of the patella and the femoral implant, in the region of the lateral condyle, can cause chronic lateral knee pain.
  • Popliteal Tendon Impingement: After TKA, the popliteal tendon can be irritated by overhand of the femoral condyles, from a posterolateral osteophyte, from residual synovium or extruded cement. Patients complain of discrete posterior knee pain that occurs after a specific point of knee flexion.
  • Protruding Medial Tibial Component: Pain along the medial knee can be from the protrusion of the tibial, including medial collateral ligament irritation. Tibial revision is necessary if pain is intolerable.
  • Nerve Injury: Deep peroneal nerve injury is a rare but reported complication of TKA, caused by compression, ischemia, traction, crush, or laceration. It typically occurs when there is surgical correction of a significant preoperative valgus deformity or flexion contracture of the knee. The infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve (IBSN) is commonly affected after knee replacement. Patients can report numbness (sometimes a painful numbness) along the lateral aspect of the knee for over a year.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome is a very rare consequence of knee replacement. It is characterized by pain disproportionate to exam findings. There is sensory disturbance (e.g., pain evoked by light brushing of the skin, called allodynia), motor impairment (e.g., weakness), and sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., edema, color changes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scar of the patellar clunk syndrome after TKR is present at the superior pole of the patella and it impinges on the femoral component of the implant of active knee extension.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amikacin

 

Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever as it is ineffective in clinical infections.

 

Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin: This macrolide antibiotic is commonly used for treating typhoid fever, especially in cases where fluoroquinolone resistance is present.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic, it has been a standard treatment for typhoid fever, though resistance to this class is increasing.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This third-generation cephalosporin is used to treat typhoid fever, particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant Salmonella typhi.

 

Educational Objective:


Amikacin is not effective in the treatment of typhoid fever, despite its efficacy in vitro against Salmonella.

choices.text: Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies
Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects
Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta
Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

questions.text: Which amongst the following is true about Turner's syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

 

In Turner's syndrome, webbing of the neck is associated with a higher risk of cardiac anomalies.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome and is characterized primarily by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies: Webbing of hands and toes is not specifically associated with Turner syndrome, nor is it a marker for visceral anomalies. Webbing or syndactyly is more commonly seen in other congenital conditions and does not relate directly to the risk of cardiac anomalies in Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects: While Noonan syndrome does indeed have a high association with cardiac defects, the question pertains specifically to Turner syndrome. Noonan syndrome and Turner syndrome have some overlapping features, but Noonan syndrome is a distinct genetic disorder that is not related to the X chromosome abnormalities seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of coarctation of aorta: This statement is incorrect. In Turner syndrome, the presence, not the absence, of neck webbing is associated with a higher risk of coarctation of the aorta and other cardiac anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Turner syndrome, the presence of neck webbing is significantly associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, particularly coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg no 318-319

questions.text: A drug used to treat Tinea cruris that is experiencing an increasing development of widespread resistance is? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terbinafine

 

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal used to treat Tinea cruris ("Jock/Dhobi itch").
  • Tinea cruris is typically caused by the fungus Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Effectiveness of terbinafine is compromised due to increasing resistance, especially in chronic or recurrent infections.
  • Resistance to terbinafine is associated with mutations in the squalene epoxidase gene, diminishing the drug’s efficacy.

 

 

  • Squalene epoxidase is vital for ergosterol synthesis, crucial for the fungal cell membrane.
  • Terbinafine-resistant fungal strains are cross-resistant to other squalene epoxidase inhibitors.

 

NOTE: Despite resistance to terbinafine, these strains remain sensitive to azoles and other antifungal classes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole:

 

  • While Itraconazole is effective against dermatophytoses, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Itraconazole inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 14α-demethylase, which is necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. This leads to accumulation of toxic intermediates and membrane dysfunction.

 

Option B. Griseofulvin:

 

  • This drug is used for treatment, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Griseofulvin binds to tubulin, disrupting the microtubule function and thereby inhibiting mitosis in fungal cells. It specifically targets dividing fungal cells.

 

Option D. Voriconazole:

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Similar to Itraconazole, Voriconazole also inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in the production of ergosterol for the fungal cell membrane.
  • It has a broad spectrum of antifungal activity. But it is not routinely used for treating superficial fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine is increasingly encountering resistance in the treatment of Tinea cruris, likely due to mutations in the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is the drug's target.

 

Online source:

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteric stone

 

Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Ureteral obstruction decreases glomerular filtration rate (GR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased renal blood flow: Correct. Increased renal blood flow increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar constriction: Correct. Efferent arteriolar constriction increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option D. Decreased oncotic pressure: Correct. Decreased oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries increases GFR by reducing the opposing colloid osmotic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Two distinct patient cohorts at AIIMS New Delhi are subjected to different treatments to monitor their post-treatment blood pressure levels. The groups do not have overlapping members. Which statistical test would best suit the analysis of the blood pressure differences between the two groups? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unpaired t test
 

  • In the provided situation, two distinct groups are under comparison, and therefore, the appropriate statistical analysis would involve employing a Student's t-test or an unpaired t-test.
  • T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t test: Used when comparing the same group before and after an intervention, not suitable for independent groups.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means among three or more groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data, not for comparing means of continuous data.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Type I collagen is not seen in? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastic cartilage

 

Elastic cartilage, as the name suggests, is more elastic than other types of cartilage. This is due to the presence of elastic fibers interspersed with the cartilage cells (chondrocytes).

 

The primary collagen in elastic cartilage is Type II collagen, not Type I.

 

Additionally, the elastin present in this cartilage gives it a yellowish appearance and makes it flexible. Examples of elastic cartilage include the external ear (auricle) and the epiglottis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone: Bone tissue primarily consists of Type I collagen. This collagen provides a framework upon which hydroxyapatite (a crystalline structure made of calcium and phosphate) can deposit, giving bones their characteristic rigidity and strength. Type I collagen provides the bone with some flexibility and tensile strength, which helps to prevent fractures.

 

Option B. Ligament: Ligaments, which connect bone to bone, are primarily composed of Type I collagen. This gives ligaments their tensile strength and ability to withstand pulling forces. The presence of Type I collagen in ligaments helps in maintaining joint stability.

 

Option C. Aponeurosis: An aponeurosis is a flat, sheet-like tendinous structure that attaches muscle to bone or other tissues. Like tendons, aponeuroses primarily contain Type I collagen. This allows aponeuroses to transmit muscular forces effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of types of collagens in various tissues:

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

 

The pedigree chart shown suggests an autosomal-recessive disorder based on several key observations:

 

  1. Horizontal Pattern: The affected individuals appear in the same generation but are not present in the preceding or subsequent generations. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal-recessive inheritance, where the disorder tends to skip generations unless both parents carry the recessive allele.
  2. Unaffected Parents: Both parents of affected individuals are unaffected, suggesting they are carriers of the recessive allele. In autosomal-recessive inheritance, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to express the disorder.
  3. Carrier Frequency: According to autosomal-recessive inheritance patterns, when both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance that their offspring will have the disorder (inherit two mutated genes), a 50% chance that the offspring will be carriers (inherit one mutated gene and one normal gene), and a 25% chance that the offspring will have a normal genotype (inherit two normal genes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal-dominant disorder: This pattern typically shows affected individuals in every generation, with both males and females equally likely to inherit the disorder. Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to their offspring, regardless of the other parent's genotype.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant disorder: This pattern would show affected females more frequently if the father is affected and can appear in every generation. However, affected males would pass the condition to all of their daughters and none of their sons.

 

Option D. X-linked recessive disorder: This pattern is more common in males, as they only have one X chromosome. Carrier females would pass the disorder to 50% of their sons, and 50% of their daughters would be carriers. However, in this pedigree, both males and females are affected equally, and the pattern does not suggest an X-linked inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the image shown below?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coxa vara

 

  • Coxa vara is a term used to describe a reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.
  • It may be congenital/acquired (growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis) or acquired (secondary to various other pathologies).
  • The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara.

 

 

  • This is coxa vara resulting from some unknown growth anomaly at the upper femoral epiphysis.
  • It is noticed as a painless limp in a child who has just started walking.
  • In severe cases, shortening of the leg may be obvious.
  • On examination, abduction and internal rotation of the hip are limited and the leg is short.
  • X-rays will show a reduction in neck-shaft angle.
  • The epiphyseal plate may be too vertical.
  • There may be a separate triangle of bone in the inferior portion of the metaphysis, called Fairbank’s triangle.

 

 

  • Treatment: Subtrochanteric corrective osteotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coxa magna. Coxa magna is the asymmetrical, circumferential enlargement and deformation of the femoral head and neck.
