It is seen in Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, transient synovitis of the hip, developmental dysplasia of the hip, trauma, septic arthritis/osteomyelitis, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, chronic slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

 

 

Option B. Coxa valga. Coxa valga is a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Bilateral coxa valga can be seen in cerebral palsy, turner syndrome. Unilateral occurs due to trauma causing growth plate arrest. Angle more than 140° is considered as coxa valga.

 

 

 

Option D. Coxa Saltans. It is a condition characterized by a snapping sensation in the hip that comprises of 3 entities: external snapping hip (caused by iliotibial tract sliding over greater trochanter), internal snapping hip (caused by iliopsoas tendon sliding over femoral head, iliopectineal ridge, lesser trochanter, and iliopsoas bursa), and intra-articular snapping hip (caused by loose body in hip/labral tears). It is common in athletes and dancers in their teens or twenties. X-ray usually appears normal. MRI may show inflamed bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows coxa vara i.e., reduced angle between the neck and shaft of the femur.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs is associated with ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is a first-line anti-tubercular drug used in combination with other medications to treat tuberculosis. One of its significant side effects is ophthalmic toxicity, specifically optic neuritis.

 

Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyl transferase, which is necessary for the synthesis of the mycobacterial cell wall.

 

Ophthalmic Toxicity:

 

  • Optic Neuritis: Ethambutol can cause inflammation of the optic nerve, leading to vision problems.
  • Symptoms: Patients may experience blurred vision, loss of visual acuity, and difficulty distinguishing between red and green colors (red-green color blindness).
  • Monitoring: It is crucial to monitor visual acuity and color vision regularly in patients taking ethambutol. Any signs of visual impairment should prompt immediate cessation of the drug and consultation with an ophthalmologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is another first-line anti-tubercular drug. Its main side effects include hepatotoxicity and peripheral neuropathy, but it is not commonly associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option C. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic used as a second-line treatment for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). It is associated with ototoxicity (hearing loss) and nephrotoxicity, not ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option D. Rifampin: Rifampin is a first-line anti-tubercular drug that can cause hepatotoxicity and discoloration of bodily fluids (e.g., urine, tears) to an orange-red color. It is not typically associated with ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol is a first line anti tubercular drug that can cause optic neuritis and red green color blindness.

choices.text: First degree of heart block

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS.

 

Loud S1 can be heard in mild MS also because loud S1 does not depend on severity of MS.

 

Loud S1 is one of the auscultatory hallmarks of MS, however it can be attenuated in a variety of conditions:

 

  • Associated MR
  • Long PR (first degree heart block)
  • CCF
  • Severe AR- regurgitant jet may impinge on AML
  • Calcified valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Here, the prolonged PR interval delays the closure of the mitral valve relative to ventricular contraction, often softening or eliminating the loud S1.

 

Option B. AR (Aortic Regurgitation): The regurgitant flow in aortic regurgitation can prevent the mitral valve leaflets from closing tightly and sharply, thus softening the S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leads to stiffening of the leaflets, which inhibits their rapid movement and thus reduces the intensity of S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically present unless there is an associated condition that affects the mobility or timing of the mitral valve leaflet closure, such as calcification, regurgitation in other valves, or disturbances in electrical conduction that affect heart rhythm

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells

 

Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells as they possess higher levels of MHC-II. They also have costimulatory membrane proteins which are required for activation of T cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

 

 

Option C. B lymphocytes: While B cells can act as antigen-presenting cells, they are not as effective as dendritic cells in stimulating naive T cells. They typically present antigens to already activated T cells rather than naive ones.

 

Option D. NK cell: Natural killer (NK) cells are involved in the innate immune response and do not function as antigen-presenting cells. They are responsible for recognizing and killing virally infected cells and tumor cells without the need for antigen presentation.

 

Educational Objective:


Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naive T cells due to their high levels of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in taste sensation?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hypoglossal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The hypoglossal nerve is purely motor cranial nerve and is not involved in taste sensation.

 

All intrinsic and the majority of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue are innervated by General Somatic Efferent fibres, which are motor fibres that supply skeletal muscles. It emerges as many rootlets from the medulla's front surface, travels laterally across the posterior cerebral fossa, and then leaves through the hypoglossal canal. All intrinsic tongue muscles, including the hyoglossus, styloglossus, and genioglossus muscles, are innervated by this nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve (CN V): The trigeminal nerve a mixed cranial nerve primarily responsible for sensations in the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. While it is not directly involved in olfaction (smell), it can indirectly influence the perception of smell. Irritants or substances that produce strong odors can activate the trigeminal nerve's pain and temperature receptors in the nasal passages, leading to sensations like "spiciness" or irritation when inhaling certain substances.

 

Option B. Vagus nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is not directly involved in olfaction. It primarily serves functions related to the autonomic nervous system, including controlling various organs and muscles in the thoracic and abdominal regions. It does not have a direct role in the sense of smell but Vagal nerve stimulation modifies the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is also a mixed cranial nerve and not directly involved in olfaction. It has various functions, including the transmission of sensory information from the back of the throat and parts of the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is primarily responsible for the motor control of the muscles of the tongue. It does not have any direct involvement in olfaction or the sense of smell.

questions.text: Inhibitory control by the hypothalamus is exerted on:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolactin and growth hormone

 

The hypothalamus exerts inhibitory control on both prolactin and growth hormone:

 

  • Prolactin: Inhibition is mediated by Prolactin-Inhibiting Hormone (PIH), which is dopamine. Dopamine inhibits the secretion of prolactin by lactotropes in the anterior pituitary.
  • Growth Hormone: Inhibition is mediated by Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone (GHIH), also known as somatostatin. Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of growth hormone by somatotropes in the anterior pituitary.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During your rural internship, you are tasked with overseeing vaccine distribution to Community Health Centres (CHCs) and Primary Health Centres (PHCs). Due to the tropical climate and frequent power outages at your posting area, ensuring the vaccines' integrity is crucial. Which of the following tests would you employ to check if the vaccines have incurred any freeze damage due to temperature fluctuations? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shake test

 

  • Utility: Used to check if Freeze sensitive vaccines have been damaged by exposure to freezing temperatures below 0 degrees C; After the test the previously Frozen vaccine shows flakes. Shake Test is used to assess the freeze damage to Aluminium based freeze sensitive vaccines such as DPT, TT, Td etc. 
  • Method of Shake test:
    • Test Vial: Vial which is suspected to have been frozen 
    • Frozen control vial: Take a similar (as Test vial) vaccine vial with same manufacturer, batch number, antigen(s), Label it properly. Freeze it overnight at -20 degrees C, then let it haw (Do not heat)
    • Hold the Test vial and Control vials between thumb and forefinger and shake them vigorously (10-15 seconds)
    • Place both vials on even flat surface for 30 minutes observation, compare the sedimentation rates (SR). If the sediments in the suspect vial settle more slowly, the suspect vaccine may be used.
  • Interpretation:
    • If SR in Test vial < Control vial: Vaccine had not been damaged
    • If SR in Test vial > Control vial: Vaccine had been damaged,

 

Do not use and Inform the supervisors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schick test: This is a skin test for susceptibility to diphtheria.

 

Option C. Habel test: This is used to measure the potency of rabies vaccines.

 

Option D. Tine test: This is a skin test for tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Shake Test currently applies to freeze sensitive vaccines which are:

 

  • DPT-Hep B-Hib
  • TT
  • PCV13
  • Hepatitis B
  • HPV

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhabdomyosarcoma  

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and histological findings. It is a malignant tumor derived from skeletal muscle and commonly presents in the pediatric population as a rapidly enlarging orbital mass, often causing displacement of the eye (proptosis). The biopsy findings of small, round cells positive for Desmin, a muscle-specific intermediate filament, support the diagnosis. The location and aggressive nature of the tumor, indicated by bony destruction, are characteristic of rhabdomyosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is a common malignant intraocular tumor of childhood but would not typically present with bony destruction or be positive for Desmin.

 

Option B. Cavernous Hemangioma: This is a benign vascular tumor seen in adults and is not associated with rapid progression or positive Desmin staining.

 

Option C. Orbital Cellulitis: This infection would present with signs of inflammation and fever, which are not described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will be first visualized to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cecum

 

The caecum is a pouch-like structure at the beginning of the colon. Visualizing the caecum first would indicate that the obstruction likely involves the large bowel if it is distended, helping to differentiate it from a small bowel obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between small and large bowel obstruction in cases of intestinal obstruction.

 

Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement, while collapsed cecum implies small bowel obstruction.

 

Identifying a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment leads to the identification of the cause.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of severe epigastric pain, she had a history of heart burn and dyspeptic symptoms for past 10 years. On physical exam, she had a temperature of 101.44° F, a pulse of 115bpm and a blood pressure of 125/72mmHg. Abdomen was tender & rigid. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum  

 

Explanation:

 

The presence of free gas under the right diaphragm in the X-ray. This is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum.

 

  • C/F: Acute abdominal pain, rigidity, tenderness, guarding
  • MOST SENSITIVE X RAY: CXR-PA erect

 

 

 

Air under the diaphragm-Right

 

  • MOST SENSITIVE Ix: CECT with oral contrast
  • NEXT STEP: Resuscitation with iv fluids, Exploratory laparotomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax which represents air in the pleural space, collapsed lung and sometimes mediastinal shift to the opposite side. Presentation is variable and may range from no symptoms to severe dyspnea with tachycardia and hypotension. 

 

Option C. Subdiaphragmatic abscess, there is an infradiaphragmatic localized collection of fluid with gas bubbles or gas-fluid level which has an enhancing wall. It is often combined with elevation of the hemidiaphragm and a pleural effusion.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction on abdominal radiographs show dilated loops of small bowel proximal to the obstruction with visible valvulae conniventes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum is a critical diagnosis identified by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on X-ray, indicative of gastrointestinal perforation, requiring immediate surgical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

This is a case of peripheral neuropathy that occurs in ATT therapy due to isoniazid (INH)

 

To treat this – Pyridoxine 10-25mg/day should be added to regimen.

 

High risk patients for peripheral neuropathy include- malnutrition, chronic alcohol dependence, diabetes, HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: While important for nervous system function, thiamine is not typically depleted by INH therapy.

 

Option C. Folic acid: Not directly related to the neurological side effects of INH.

 

Option D. Methylcobalamin: Though important for nerve health, it is not the primary vitamin depleted by INH therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: What does the following image show? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

 

The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage. In this case, a band neutrophil is seen inside a megakaryocyte.

 

A rare biological phenomenon called emperipolesis involves a cell penetrating another live cell. In emperipolesis, as opposed to phagocytosis, when the enveloped cell is destroyed by the macrophage's lysosomal enzymes, the cell can exit at any time without causing any structural or functional problems for either of them. This process can be either physiological or pathological. Histiocytes and Megakaryocytes generally participate in peripolesis. It is seen in Rosai-Dorfman disease and Hodgkin's disease are pathological circumstances when this process is observed.

 

NOTE:

 

Emperipolesis vs Entosis:

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

Entosis, on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and Entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autophagy: This process involves the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery.

 

Option C. Phagocytosis: The process by which a cell engulfs and digests foreign particles or cells, typically leading to the degradation of the engulfed material.

 

Option D. Amoebic autophagy: Not a recognized term; may be confused with autophagy or phagocytosis processes seen in amoebas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emperipolesis is a unique process where one cell enters another without being destroyed, differentiating it from phagocytosis and entosis, with the host cell usually being a megakaryocyte or histiocyte.

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic contact dermatitis among construction workers in India? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromate

 

  • It is a component of chromium, is commonly used in the manufacturing of cement and is a well-known cause of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) among construction workers due to their frequent and prolonged exposure to wet cement.
  • Chromate can cause ACD through a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • When cement containing chromate comes into contact with the skin, particularly in the presence of moisture, the chromate can leach out and result in sensitization and subsequent dermatitis.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response to an allergen that only manifests as an eruption in people who have already been sensitized to the allergen.
  • The diagnosis of ACD is made by Patch test with the culprit substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt: Cobalt is less commonly a cause of ACD in construction workers compared to chromate. Cobalt may be present in tools or dyes, but not typically in cement.

 

Option B. Nickel: Nickel is a well-known cause of ACD, often associated with exposure to nickel-containing jewellery or clothing items, not with cement.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron, while common in construction materials, is not a frequent cause of ACD. It is not known to be an allergen that would typically induce contact dermatitis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among construction workers in India, allergic contact dermatitis is most commonly caused by chromate in cement, due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction when chromate comes into contact with the skin.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.2-14

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

choices.text: 6 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months
7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months
4 drugs for 4 months followed by 6 drugs for 10-12 months
5 drugs for 6 months followed by 4 drugs for 12 months

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). According to the World Health Organization's guidelines, which of the following treatment schedules is recommended? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 drugs for 4-6 months followed by 4 drugs for 5 months

 

  • WHO defines Multi-drug resistant (MDR) Tuberculosis strain as Resistant to INH and Rifampicin with or without resistant to other anti TB drugs

 

Treatment of MDR-TB:

 

  • DOTS PLUS (Older name: Category IV)
  • Must be done on basis of sensitivity testing
  • Directly observed therapy certainly helps to improve outcomes and is considered an integral part of MDR-TB treatment
    • The recommended treatment regimen for multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) involves a two-phase approach.
    • In the initial phase, patients are prescribed a combination of seven drugs for a duration of 4 to 6 months. These seven drugs are collectively referred to as CHOBZEE, which stands for Clofazimine, High dose Isoniazid, Levofloxacin, Bedaquiline, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Ethionamide.
    • Following the initial phase, the treatment enters a second phase where four drugs are continued for an additional 5 months. These four drugs are collectively known as COZE, consisting of Clofazimine, Levofloxacin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol. Note: Bedaquiline is always given for 6 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

New Regimens for Treatment Drug Resistant TB (RNTCP 2017-18)

 

 

(Drugs: Hh: High dose isoniazid; E:Ethambutol; Z:Pyrazinamide; K:Kanamycin; Cm: Capreomycin; A Amikacin; L: Levofloxacin; M: Moxifloxacin; Mh: High dose moxifloxacin; Et; Ethionamide; Cs: Cycloserine; Cz: Clofazimine; Lz: Linezolid; Bq: Bedaquiline

questions.text: A Patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160bpm. His BP is 96/68mmHg. What is the next step in management? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid sinus massage.

 

Above ECG findings – narrow complex tachycardia without P waves with clinical finding of sudden onset palpitations suggest AV node reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

 

Next best step in management will be carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver).

 

Vagal maneuvers can terminate an approximate 10-20% of AVNRT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenosine: Used if vagal maneuver fail, adenosine is the drug of choice because it can temporarily block AV node conduction and terminate reentrant tachycardias.

 

Option C. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are another pharmacological option if adenosine fails, used to slow the heart rate and control the symptoms.

 

Option D. Defibrillator: Not appropriate in this scenario as the patient is hemodynamically stable (SBP >90 mmHg) and the tachycardia does not pose an immediate threat to life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carotid sinus massage is the first-line intervention for clinically stable patients presenting with AVNRT, potentially stopping the arrhythmia without the need for drug intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following does not favor euchromatin formation due to changes occurring at Cytosine residues at Cp islands in DNA?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylation 

 

Euchromatin is a form of chromatin that is loosely packed and transcriptionally active, allowing for the expression of genes. The formation and maintenance of euchromatin are influenced by various post-translational modifications of DNA and histones.

 

Methylation of Cytosine Residues at CpG Islands:

 

  • CpG Islands: These are regions of DNA with a high frequency of CpG dinucleotides, often found near gene promoters and regulatory regions.
  • Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues in CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of heterochromatin (inactive, condensed chromatin). This methylation process hinders the binding of transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, leading to a more compact chromatin structure and reduced gene expression.
  • Impact on Euchromatin: Methylation of cytosine residues is a key epigenetic modification that does not favor euchromatin formation because it inactivates the DNA, leading to a transcriptionally inactive state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphorylation: Phosphorylation of histones can promote chromatin remodeling and gene expression, thus favoring euchromatin formation.

 

Option C. Alkylation: Alkylation typically refers to the addition of alkyl groups to DNA or histones, which can have varying effects. However, it does not specifically inhibit euchromatin formation in the way that methylation does.

 

Option D. Sumoylation: Sumoylation involves the addition of small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO) proteins to histones or other proteins. This modification generally influences protein stability and function, but it does not directly interfere with euchromatin formation like methylation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methylation of cytosine residues at CpG islands is associated with gene silencing and the formation of transcriptionally inactive heterochromatin, thus not favoring euchromatin formation.

questions.text: The most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis is? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphology

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperm is considered the most important marker of male fertility. While sperm concentration and progressive motility are valuable for distinguishing between fertile and infertile men, strict sperm morphology is the most discriminating factor in assessing male fertility potential.

 

Morphological abnormalities in spermatozoa can be identified in various parts, including the head, neck, mid-piece, and tail. These abnormalities can result from defective spermatogenesis or certain epididymal pathologies, leading to increased morphological defects in the sperm. Spermatozoa with abnormal morphology have a lower fertilizing potential, making morphology a critical parameter in semen analysis for determining fertility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Concentration: Sperm concentration is an important parameter, but it is not as critical as morphology in predicting fertility. The WHO 2021 standard for sperm concentration is 16 million/ml.

 

Option C. Motility: Progressive motility is significant, with the WHO 2021 standard being 30%, but it is not the most crucial parameter compared to morphology.

 

Option D. Sperm Count: While total sperm count is important, it is encompassed under concentration and motility measures. Morphology remains the most critical individual parameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis, as it directly correlates with the fertilizing potential of the sperm.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg443, https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Advance directive

 

The Mental Health Care Act 2017 introduced a provision allowing individuals to specify in advance the manner in which they would like to be cared for and treated in the event they develop a mental illness in the future. This provision is called an "Advance Directive." The advance directive allows a person to specify how they want to be treated, what treatments they don't want, and to nominate a person to be their representative.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions. Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip
Trendelenburg with legs stirrup

questions.text: A woman presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is being taken for a Cesarean section. Which of the following is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on the OT table? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supine with wedge under right hip

 

Explanation:

 

The preferred position for a cesarean section is supine with a wedge under the right hip. This positioning is crucial to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is commonly seen in the third trimester of pregnancy.

 

Supine hypotension syndrome:

 

  • Occurs due to the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava (IVC) when the patient is in the supine position.
  • This pressure can cause hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope.
  • It is particularly dangerous during cesarean sections where spinal anesthesia can exacerbate hypotension.
  • A right tilt (placing a wedge under the right hip) helps to alleviate the pressure on the IVC, thereby preventing hypotension.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Semi fowlers: The individual lies on the bed with the head elevated 30-45 degrees. This position is not suitable for a cesarean section.

 

Option C. Trendelenburg with legs stirrup: This position involves having the head low and is not appropriate for a cesarean section. The reverse Trendelenburg position (head high) is also not suitable for this purpose.

 

Option D. Prone position: The prone position (lying face down) is inappropriate for cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a cesarean section, the patient should be positioned supine with a wedge under the right hip to prevent supine hypotension syndrome, which is caused by the pressure of the gravid uterus on the inferior vena cava.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1405

questions.text: NARP syndrome is a? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial function disorder

 

NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as a mitochondrial function disorder.

 

NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. Most individuals with NARP have a specific MT-ATP6 genetic change in 70 percent to 90 percent of their mitochondria. NARP syndrome is inherited from the mother (maternal inheritance) because only females pass mitochondrial DNA to their children.

 

It has 2 phenotypes:

 

  • NARP
  • Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS)

 

It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial DNA load in the tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosomal storage disorder: Lysosomal storage disorders result from defects in lysosomal function, leading to the accumulation of undigested macromolecules. Examples include Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher disease. NARP syndrome is not related to lysosomal function.

 

Option C. Glycogen storage disorder: Glycogen storage disorders involve defects in the metabolism of glycogen, leading to its accumulation in tissues. Examples include Pompe disease and McArdle disease. NARP syndrome is not a glycogen storage disorder.

 

Option D. Golgi body transport disorder: Disorders of the Golgi apparatus involve defects in protein and lipid processing and trafficking. Examples include congenital disorders of glycosylation. NARP syndrome is not related to Golgi body transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NARP syndrome is a mitochondrial function disorder caused by a point mutation in the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene, leading to a spectrum of neurological and retinal symptoms.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 2572

choices.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.text: How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Connexons are involved in electrical synapse

 

 

Electrical synapses are characterized by direct open fluid channels that conduct electricity from one cell to the next. Most of these consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions (connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next. By way of gap junctions and other similar junctions that action potentials are transmitted from one smooth muscle fiber to the next in visceral smooth muscle and from one cardiac muscle cell to the next in cardiac muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane: Incorrect. This statement describes chemical synapses, not electrical synapses.

 

Option B. Direction of impulse is unidirectional: Incorrect. Electrical synapses can conduct impulses bidirectionally, whereas chemical synapses typically conduct impulses unidirectionally.

 

Option D. Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse: Incorrect. Electrical synapses have a shorter latent period compared to chemical synapses due to the direct transfer of ions through connexons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Electrical synapses involve connexons, which are gap junctions that allow direct ion flow between adjacent cells, facilitating rapid and synchronized electrical communication.

choices.text: Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid

questions.text: The correct pair of lymph node level in the neck and anatomical boundaries amongst the following are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Level 6 - Hyoid to clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

The correct pair of lymph nodes and levels among the following options are level 6- Hyoid to clavicle.

 

Level 6 lymph nodes are the anterior or central compartment nodes. They span from the hyoid bone (superiorly) to the sternum/clavicle (inferiorly), and from the carotid arteries laterally. This group includes pretracheal, paratracheal, and precricoid (Delphian) nodes. These nodes often come into consideration in thyroid cancers and some laryngeal and hypopharyngeal malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle: This is incorrect. Level 3 lymph nodes are located in the middle jugular region, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the hyoid bone (superiorly) and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (inferiorly). They are situated along the middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid: This is also incorrect. Level 4 lymph nodes are the lower jugular nodes, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (superiorly) and the clavicle (inferiorly). These nodes are situated along the inferior third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid: This is not correct. Level 5 lymph nodes are located in the posterior triangle of the neck, which is bound by the sternocleidomastoid muscle (anteriorly), the trapezius muscle (posteriorly), and the clavicle (inferiorly). Level 5 is further divided into Level 5A (located above the cricoid) and Level 5B (located below the cricoid to the clavicle). So, Level 5 spans from the base of the skull to the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -

 

To aid in the description and localization of lymph nodes, especially in cancer treatment and surgery, they have been categorized into specific levels. Each level is defined by anatomical landmarks.

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

An early diastolic murmur in the right 2nd intercostal space is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to be associated with the above findings.

 

BP difference between arms is classical due to blood jet projected towards right brachiocephalic artery, but the murmur of AR is very rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarctation of the Aorta: Can sometimes show differences in arm blood pressures, especially if the coarctation is proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is also associated with a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to AR.

 

Option C. Takayasu Arteritis: Known for causing vascular inflammation leading to stenoses, which can result in differing blood pressures in the arms. About 25% of patients may also have AR.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: Typically presents with differential blood pressure between arms and can rapidly lead to AR due to involvement of the aortic root.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: Craniopagus is defined as the fusion of? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head only

 

Craniopagus refers to a type of conjoined twins where the twins are fused at the cranium (head). This type of conjoined twin fusion involves the skulls but does not typically involve the face or the foramen magnum. Although the brains of craniopagus twins are usually separate, there may be some shared brain tissue, which can sometimes be discovered.

 

Craniopagus twins generally have fused skulls and meninges (the membranes covering the brain), making separation surgeries particularly complex and risky. These twins are genetically identical and are always of the same sex.

 

Craniopagus occurs in approximately 5% of conjoined twin cases, and the prognosis after separation surgery is often poor due to the complexity of the shared structures.

 

Types of Conjoined Twins:

 

  • Abdomen (omphalopagus): Fusion occurs at the abdomen.
  • Chest (thoracopagus): Fusion occurs at the thorax.
  • Top of head down to the belly button, facing each other (cephalopagus): Fusion occurs from the top of the head down to the belly button.
  • Head only (craniopagus): Fusion occurs at the cranium.
  • Pelvis, facing each other (ischiopagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins facing each other.
  • Pelvis, side-to-side (parapagus): Fusion occurs at the pelvis with the twins side-by-side.
  • Vertebral column (rachipagus): Fusion occurs at the vertebral column.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head and spine: This type of fusion is not characteristic of craniopagus, which involves only the head.

 

Option C. Thorax and spine: This type of fusion does not apply to craniopagus twins but could describe other forms like thoracopagus or rachipagus.

 

Option D. Thorax only: This describes thoracopagus twins, where the fusion occurs at the thorax, not the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopagus is a specific type of conjoined twins where the fusion occurs only at the cranium (head), and these twins are genetically identical and of the same sex.

questions.text: Heller's operation is performed for: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The most common surgical procedure done for achalasia cardia is laparoscopic Heller myotomy in conjugation with partial fundoplication.

 

Heller's operation is most commonly performed to treat Achalasia cardia. Achalasia is a medical condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax properly, leading to difficulty in swallowing and the accumulation of food in the esophagus. Heller myotomy involves cutting the muscles of the LES to alleviate the obstruction and improve the passage of food into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma esophagus: Cancer of the esophagus is typically treated with other approaches such as surgery to remove the tumor, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or a combination of these treatments.

 

Option C. Esophageal stricture: Esophageal stricture refers to the narrowing of the esophagus, often due to scar tissue formation. Treatment for esophageal strictures may involve dilation procedures or other surgical techniques depending on the underlying cause.

 

Option D. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically involves a surgical procedure called Ramsteads pyloromyotomy to alleviate the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia, commonly referred to as achalasia, is a medical condition that affects the esophagus, specifically the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and the muscles of the esophageal wall. This condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  1. Failure of LES Relaxation: In achalasia, the LES, a muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the stomach, does not relax properly during swallowing. Normally, the LES should relax to allow food and liquids to pass into the stomach, but in achalasia, this relaxation is impaired.
  2. Incomplete Emptying of the Esophagus: Due to the dysfunctional LES, the esophagus is unable to empty food and liquids into the stomach efficiently. This leads to a gradual buildup of food and fluids in the esophagus, causing symptoms.
  3. Difficulty in Swallowing: The most prominent symptom of achalasia is dysphagia, which is difficulty in swallowing. Patients often experience a sensation of food getting stuck in the chest while eating and may need to drink fluids or change their body position to help food pass into the stomach.
  4. Regurgitation: As a result of the esophageal emptying problems, patients with achalasia may also experience regurgitation of undigested food, often occurring at night when lying down.
  5. Chest Pain: Some individuals with achalasia may experience chest pain or discomfort, often due to the accumulation of food and fluids in the esophagus.

 

Achalasia is typically diagnosed through tests such as esophageal manometry, which measures the pressure within the esophagus, and barium swallow studies, which show the narrowing of the esophagus and the delayed emptying of contrast material.

 

Treatment options for achalasia include:

 

  • Heller Myotomy: This surgical procedure involves cutting the muscles of the LES to allow for improved passage of food and liquids into the stomach. It is the primary surgical treatment for achalasia.
  • Pneumatic Dilation: In this non-surgical procedure, a balloon is inflated within the LES to stretch and disrupt the muscle fibers, making it easier for food to pass.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injection: Injecting botulinum toxin directly into the LES can help relax the muscle temporarily. However, this treatment may need to be repeated periodically.

 

The choice of treatment depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the severity of the condition. Effective management of achalasia can alleviate symptoms and improve the quality of life for individuals with this disorder.

questions.text: The presence of a pearly white papule on the mother's forehead, which is also seen in her infant, can be due to which of the following virus? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pox virus

 

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It’s a DNA virus.

 

  • It is mainly caused by Pox virus which is a DNA virus.
  • Virus: Molluscum Contagiosum Virus (MCV).
    • MCV-1: Children over Face (Not seen over palms & soles).
    • MCV-2: Adults producing lesions over Genitals.
  • Microscopic examination - Lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies.
  • Transmission: Skin to skin contact.

 

Note: Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Usually, it is self-limiting and will disappear by itself. Thus, there is no need for treatment.
  • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) leads to warts, but the lesions are typically rough-surfaced as shown in the image below, rather than pearly.

 

 

  • Option C. Adenovirus does not typically cause visible skin manifestations like the one shown.
  • Option D. Herpes virus causes vesicular and ulcerative lesions as shown in the image below, rather than pearly papules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pearly white papules in both a mother and her infant is indicative of molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by a Poxvirus.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25, Page no 25.12-14

questions.text: A patient's plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Virus

 

Interferon-beta (IFN-β) is a type I interferon, which is predominantly secreted in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the immune response to pathogens, particularly viruses. They help inhibit viral replication within host cells and activate immune cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacteria: Bacterial infections are primarily associated with pro-inflammatory cytokines like IL-1, TNF-α, and IL-6, rather than type I interferons.

 

Option C. Fungi: Fungal infections do not typically induce high levels of interferon-beta.

 

Option D. Mycoplasm: Mycoplasma infections are more likely to induce other immune responses rather than a significant increase in interferon-beta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of interferons:

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the nutritional targets of Mid-Day Meal Program, as per the Indian government guidelines? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1/2 protein and 1/3 calorie requirements

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
    • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
    • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
    • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
    • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
    • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal -

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Natural deficiency of riboflavin in man is uncommon, because riboflavin is synthesized by the intestinal flora. Riboflavin deficiency usually accompanies other deficiency diseases such as beriberi, pellagra and Kwashiorkor. Nutritional status of riboflavin can be determined by measuring the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

 

Manifestations: Symptoms are confined to skin and mucous membranes.

 

  1. Glossitis (Greek, glossa = tongue)
  2. Magenta colored tongue
  3. Cheilosis (Greek, cheilos = lip)
  4. Angular stomatitis (inflammation at the corners of mouth)
  5. Circumcorneal vascularization
  6. Proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries is the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency.
  7. Personality changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Deficiency causes beriberi, which affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, but is detected by erythrocyte transketolase activation assay.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): Deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy and is detected by activation of erythrocyte transaminases.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, detected by serum methyl malonate and homocysteine levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency, indicated by reduced glutathione reductase activity, can cause symptoms such as a fissured tongue, cheilosis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: The factors that can cause a person to drink water due to stimulation of thirst mechanism is/are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Dehydration, hemorrhage, and prandial drinking: All three can cause increased thirst resulting in water drinking.

 

Option A. Dehydration: Loss of body fluids leads to increased osmolarity, which stimulates osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus, triggering the sensation of thirst.

 

Option B. Hemorrhage: Significant blood loss decreases blood volume and blood pressure, activating the thirst mechanism to restore fluid balance.

 

Option C. Prandial Drinking: Drinking during meals helps facilitate digestion and maintains hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following image depicts: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Production of monoclonal antibodies

 

The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

 

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

 

 

The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.

 

Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell lines for viral culture: This option is incorrect as the process depicted is not related to culturing cells for viral growth, but rather for antibody production.

 

Option C. Vaccine synthesis: This option is incorrect because vaccine synthesis generally involves the creation of attenuated or inactivated pathogens or their components, not the production of monoclonal antibodies.

 

Option D. Process of genetic engineering: This option is incorrect as genetic engineering involves manipulating an organism's genes directly, whereas the process depicted is about producing antibodies through hybridoma technology.

 

Educational Objective:


The process depicted in the images is the production of monoclonal antibodies using hybridoma technology.

questions.text: In the infectious disease ward, you notice a multi-drug therapy packet placed neatly on a patient's bedside table. Based on the drug composition, which of the following diseases do you think the packet is intended to treat? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leprosy

 

The given image shows the adult blister packet used in the treatment of leprosy.

 

 

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB: TB treatment involves a different combination of drugs, typically including isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.

 

Option C. Vaginal discharge: Treatment for vaginal discharge depends on the specific cause, such as bacterial, fungal, or protozoal infection, and usually involves single-agent therapy.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea treatment generally involves antibiotics like ceftriaxone and azithromycin, not a multi-drug blister packet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multi-drug therapy packets containing drugs like rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone are specifically intended for the treatment of leprosy.

choices.text: Glycogenesis in muscle
Increased protein synthesis
Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA
Decreased cholesterol synthesis

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl suffers from an inadequately treated type 1 diabetes mellitus. She is currently hyperglycemic. Which of the following is most likely to occur? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). In cases like Type 1 diabetes mellitus where insulin is deficient, uninhibited activity of HSL in adipocytes leads to breakdown of lipid into fatty acids (lipolysis) which will further undergo beta-oxidation and produce a large amount of acetyl CoA. This then gets converted to ketone bodies (acetoacetate, acetone, beta-hydroxybutyrate, etc.)

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Glycogenesis in Muscle: Glycogenesis (formation of glycogen from glucose) is stimulated by insulin. In the absence of insulin, glycogenesis is decreased, not increased.

 

Option B. Increased Protein Synthesis: Insulin promotes protein synthesis. In its absence, as in type 1 diabetes mellitus, protein synthesis is decreased, and protein catabolism is increased.

 

Option D. Decreased Cholesterol Synthesis: While insulin does influence cholesterol synthesis, the primary metabolic changes in type 1 diabetes mellitus are related to glucose and lipid metabolism. The increased lipolysis and subsequent ketogenesis are more pronounced effects.

 

Educational Objective

 

In type 1 diabetes mellitus with inadequate insulin, the most likely occurrence is the increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA due to uninhibited hormone-sensitive lipase activity, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent ketogenesis.

questions.text: A patient has complained of fever with chills. A throat examination reveals swollen glands and a thick, whitish membrane over his tonsils. Albert staining is to be done. What are the constituents of Albert's stain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toluidine and malachite green

 

Albert stain is used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria, such as those seen in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The staining technique involves two solutions: Albert stain 1 and Albert stain 2. Albert stain 1 contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, which are basic dyes with a high affinity for acidic tissue components like cytoplasm. Toluidine blue stains the granules blue, while Malachite green provides a green background. This differential staining helps in visualizing the metachromatic granules distinctly.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbol fuschin and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect as Carbol fuschin is used in Ziehl-Neelsen staining for acid-fast bacteria, and methylene blue is a counterstain in that procedure.

 

Option B. Carbol fuschin and malachite green: This combination is incorrect because Carbol fuschin is not used in Albert staining; it is used in acid-fast staining procedures.

 

Option D. Toluidine and methylene blue: This combination is incorrect for Albert staining. Methylene blue is a basic dye used in various other staining techniques, but not in Albert stain.

 

Educational Objective:


Albert stain contains Toluidine blue and Malachite green, used to identify metachromatic granules in bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

choices.text: Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm
Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation
Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent

questions.text: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, 2018 was awarded to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for which of the following discoveries? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation

 

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2018 was awarded jointly to James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo for their pioneering work in cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Their research focused on understanding how the immune system can be harnessed to fight cancer, specifically through the mechanism of immune checkpoint inhibitors.

 

  • James P. Allison discovered that the protein CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte-associated protein 4) acts as a brake on T cells. By inhibiting CTLA-4, it is possible to boost the immune system's response against cancer cells.
  • Tasuku Honjo discovered a different protein, PD-1 (programmed cell death protein 1), which also functions as an immune checkpoint. Blocking PD-1 can similarly enhance the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells.

 

These discoveries have led to the development of drugs known as immune checkpoint inhibitors, which have significantly improved treatment outcomes for various types of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discovery of mechanisms of autophagy: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2016 was awarded to Yoshinori Ohsumi for his discoveries of mechanisms for autophagy, a fundamental process for degrading and recycling cellular components.

 

Option B. Discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2017 was awarded to Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash, and Michael W. Young for their discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm.

 

Option D. Discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2012 was awarded to John B. Gurdon and Shinya Yamanaka for the discovery that mature cells can be reprogrammed to become pluripotent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immune checkpoint inhibitors function by blocking the proteins that control the immune system's reactions to cancer cells. The immune system's brake is removed when these proteins are inhibited, making it easier for T cells to more efficiently eliminate cancer cells.

 

James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo were awarded the 2018 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy through inhibition of negative immune regulation.

questions.text: As a young pediatrician practicing in India, you attend various workshops and training sessions to keep yourself updated with the latest guidelines in child health. During one such session focused on India's National Immunization Program, you discuss with your colleagues about the range of vaccines included in the program. Which of the following vaccines is NOT currently part of India's National Immunization Program? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Influenza

 

  • The Influenza vaccine (commonly known as the Flu shot) has not yet been included in India's National Immunization Programme.
  • It's important to note that the Bacterial Hemophilus influenzae type-b (Hib) vaccine is distinct from the viral Influenza (Flu) vaccine.
  • The HiB vaccine is included as part of the pentavalent vaccine (DPT + HiB + HepB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

choices.text: NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via lgE antibodies).

 

In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

 

 

Role of NK Cells: NK cells are key mediators of ADCC. They express the Fc receptor CD16 (FcγRIII), which specifically recognizes the Fc portion of IgG antibodies bound to target cells. Upon engagement, NK cells degranulate, releasing cytotoxic molecules that induce apoptosis in the target cell.

 

Role of Neutrophils and Eosinophils: Eosinophils are particularly involved in the ADCC response against larger parasites, such as helminths, where they utilize IgE antibodies to recognize and attack these pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is primarily mediated by NK cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which kill target cells coated with antibodies through mechanisms that do not involve phagocytosis.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 356

choices.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

 

Stenopaeic slit is not used in corneal tattooing.

 

Corneal tattooing was introduced as an attempt to mask the leukomatous opacities of the eye during ancient times. Corneal tattooing is also found to reduce glare within the eye due to iris loss and increase visual acuity.

 

Many different types of inks are used throughout history and today for the dyeing of the cornea. Today, India ink is the most commonly used, providing safe and long-lasting effects, but other dyes include metallic colors in powder form, various organic dyes, and uveal pigment from animal eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fincham's test: Used specifically to evaluate differences in the nature of halos seen by patients, aiding in the differential diagnosis between cataract and glaucoma.

 

Option C. Optical Iridectomy: The stenopaeic slit assists in locating the best area on the cornea for performing an iridectomy, essential in cases where peripheral vision needs to be preserved.

 

Option D. To find out the axis in astigmatism: It is instrumental in determining the precise axis for corrective lenses, which is vital for proper astigmatism management.

 

STENOPAEIC SLIT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uses of stenopaeic slit test:

 

  • Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • To find out the axis in astigmatism.

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastin fibres

 

Explanation:

 

Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.

 

The ventral portions of the laminae of nearby vertebrae are connected by a network of ligaments called the Ligament flava. They make up a portion of the posterior surface of the spinal canal and primarily consist of elastic tissue. Because it contains a lot of elastin, it can be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm. The ligamentum flava helps with extension back to the anatomical position by helping to prevent laminae separation during flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 collagen: Collagen is the primary structural protein, among the different types of collagen, Type 1 collagen is the most abundant. It's found in many tissues including skin, tendons, internal organs, and the organic part of bones. Its primary function is to provide tensile strength to these tissues. It forms strong fibers and is responsible for the strength of the tissue. However, while present in many areas of the body, Type 1 collagen is not the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Option B. Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in cartilaginous tissues. Its main function is to provide resistance against intermittent pressure, making it ideal for cartilaginous structures like the intervertebral discs, hyaline cartilage, and the vitreous humor of the eye. Given that ligamentum flavum is not a cartilaginous structure, Type 2 collagen is not its predominant component.

 

Option C. Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers are a type of fiber in connective tissue composed of Type 3 collagen. These fibers form a mesh-like framework in various organs such as the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. They provide a supportive framework for these and other organs. While they are present in various parts of the body, they are not the main component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligamentum flavum, which connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae, contains a high concentration of elastin fibers, which allows the ligament to stretch during spine flexion and then return to its original shape when the spine is extended.

 

This characteristic helps maintain the stability and alignment of the vertebral column. Thus, among the given options, elastin fibers are the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: What is the minimum endometrial thickness on transvaginal ultrasonography, above which you perform a biopsy in a case of postmenopausal bleeding? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4 mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post menopausal bleeding with a finding of endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm (5 mm or more) requires further evaluation, i.e., a biopsy of the endometrium.
  • If the endometrial thickness is ≤4 mm, then malignancy is unlikely and the likely cause of bleeding being endometrial atrophy and there is no need of a biopsy.
  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is atrophic endometritis

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with bleeding, an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm on transvaginal ultrasonography should prompt further evaluation with an endometrial biopsy to rule out malignancy or other significant pathology.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 186, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 357

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is another helminth with a similar skin-penetrating infection method, but its life cycle is characterized by direct development into adult worms in the intestine after migration, without a free-living phase.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: This helminth has a different life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which then hatch in the intestine, and larvae migrate through the liver and lungs before maturing in the intestine.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Known as pinworm, this helminth has a life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the intestine, and the adult worms live in the colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

questions.text: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatotoxicity

 

  • Valproate is metabolized by CYP450 enzymes into a minor metabolite, which is hepatotoxic.
  • Enzyme inducers like carbamazepine phenytoin and Phenobarbital can induce the microsomal enzyme and increase production of this metabolite. This increases the risk of hepatotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis: While valproate is associated with a risk of pancreatitis, the addition of carbamazepine does not specifically increase this risk. Pancreatitis is a rare but serious side effect of valproate alone.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia can be a side effect of valproate, but it is not specifically increased by the addition of carbamazepine. Thrombocytopenia results from bone marrow suppression, which is not directly affected by carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia: Hyperammonemia is a known side effect of valproate and can lead to encephalopathy. However, carbamazepine does not exacerbate this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, there is an increased risk of hepatotoxicity due to the induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes by carbamazepine, leading to increased production of a hepatotoxic metabolite of valproate.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate was admitted to the NICU after he was observed to have movements as shown in the image. His APGAR scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His blood sugar was within the normal range in the first 24 hours. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focal clonic seizure.

 

The movements depicted in the clip are indicative of a focal clonic seizure. In neonates, focal clonic seizures are characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. These contractions can involve the limbs, face, or trunk. Key characteristics of focal clonic seizures include:

 

  1. Unifocal or multifocal: The seizure may involve muscle groups on one side of the body (unifocal) or multiple regions (multifocal).
  2. Synchronous or asynchronous: The movements can occur either in a coordinated manner (synchronously) or in an uncoordinated manner (asynchronously) across different muscle groups.
  3. Resistant to restraint: The movements are involuntary and cannot be suppressed by restraining the affected limb or body part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal tonic seizure: In contrast to focal clonic seizures, focal tonic seizures involve sustained posturing of a single limb, asymmetrical trunk posturing, or sustained ocular deviation. These postures are not influenced by external stimulation or restraint.

 

Option C. Spasms: Neonatal spasms are characterized by sudden, generalized jerks that last approximately 1-2 seconds. These spasms often occur in clusters and can be classified as flexor, extensor, or a combination of both. Unlike clonic seizures, spasms are not triggered or suppressed by stimulation or restraint.

 

Option D. Subtle seizure: Subtle seizures in neonates may present with less noticeable symptoms such as eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing movements, or abnormal extremity motions (e.g., rowing, swimming, cycling). Other signs may include changes in heart rate, episodes of hypertension, or apnea. These seizures are more common in premature infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Focal clonic seizures in neonates involve repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups that are resistant to restraint and can be unifocal or multifocal.

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign on MRI is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arachnoiditis

 

Explanation:

 

The empty thecal sac sign, which appears on MRI as an apparent absence or clumping of the nerve roots within the thecal sac, is indicative of arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is an inflammation of the arachnoid linings of the spinal canal, which can cause the nerve roots to clump together and adhere to one another or the lining of the canal, leaving the thecal sac appearing empty or devoid of its normal content of floating nerve roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Discitis: An inflammation of the intervertebral disc, which would not typically show the empty thecal sac sign but might show disc space narrowing and endplate erosions.

 

Option C. Vertebral osteomyelitis: An infection of the vertebral bodies, generally presenting with bony destruction, soft tissue swelling, and possibly an abscess but not the empty thecal sac sign.

 

Option D. Tethered cord syndrome: Characterized by an abnormally low conus medullaris with associated thickened filum terminale, not typically associated with the empty thecal sac sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI of Arachnoiditis shows Empty thecal sac sign.

Due to inflammation, nerve roots are clumped and empty thecal sac are seen on MRI of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is based on RNA? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RT-PCR

 

RT PCR is RNA-based technique.

 

It is the method used to amplify, isolate or identify a known sequence from a cell or tissue RNA library. Essentially normal PCR is preceded by reverse transcription (to convert the RNA to cDNA). This is widely used in expression mapping, determining when and where certain genes are expressed. Tth polymerase from Thermus thermophilus may be used. This enzyme has both DNA polymerase and reverse transcriptase activities at high temperature. This allows both cDNA synthesis from mRNA followed by PCR amplification.

In ordinary PCR, DNA is detected; that DNA could be from a living or non-living organism. But in reverse PCR, mRNA is detected; that means, it is derived from a living organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sanger's technique - Sanger sequencing, also known as the “chain termination method”, is a method for determining the nucleotide sequence of DNA.

 

Option C. Next-generation DNA sequencing technologies also called deep sequencing, is a technology that enables parallel multiplexed analysis of DNA sequences on a massive scale.

 

Option D. Western blot is used to detect specific protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is an RNA-based technique that involves reverse transcription of RNA into cDNA followed by PCR amplification, widely used in gene expression analysis.

questions.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap is seen in all except? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Salicylate poisoning.

 

Metabolic acidosis can present with either a normal or elevated anion gap. Salicylate poisoning characteristically causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of organic acids like lactic acid and ketoacids. It can initially present with a respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center, followed by metabolic acidosis as the condition progresses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis): This causes a normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis due to bicarbonate loss in the urine.

 

Option B. Pancreatitis: Can lead to normal anion gap acidosis if associated with diarrhea or other mechanisms leading to bicarbonate loss.

 

Option C. Severe diarrhea: Leads to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis due to significant loss of bicarbonate in stool.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Among the following, what is the most common symptom of adult obsessive-compulsive disorder? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pathological doubt

 

Pathological doubt is one of the most common symptoms in adult obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). People with OCD frequently doubt whether they've done something correctly, whether it's locking the door, turning off the stove, or other everyday tasks (obsession). This doubt leads them to repeatedly check or perform rituals to alleviate their anxiety (compulsion).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aggressive symptoms, Option B. Need for symmetry, and Option D. Sexual symptoms are also seen in OCD, but the constant doubt and resultant checking rituals are among the most characteristic and prevalent symptoms of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In adult OCD, most common presentation is obsession of contamination with compulsion of washing, followed by pathological doubt and checking rituals.

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 96.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG to see cervical length

 

Explanation:
